3. omi uva data the omi is nadir viewing and onboard a nasa eos aura spacecraft flying in a sunsynchronous polar orbit

the omi spectral irradiance data at solar noon in the uva waveband at 324 nm and 380 nm is provided, as well as in the uvb waveband at 305 nm and 310 nm and the solar noon daily erythemal irradiance, the solar noon uv index and the erythemal daily exposure
the omi-based evaluation is of the order of 7% to 30% higher than the ground measured data

the omi spectral irradiance data at solar noon in the uva waveband at 324 nm and 380 nm, as well as in the uvb waveband at 305 nm and 310 nm, are available from the nasa ges-disc interactive online visualization and analysis infrastructure (giovanni) website where ges-disc is the goddard earth sciences data and information services center

once the plot is produced on the screen, the selection of the downloads option on the left allows the file to be downloaded in , the omi global spatial distribution of the erythemal uv and the irradiances at 305 nm, 310 nm, 324 nm and 380 nm data for a given time can be plotted via the giovanni website
the omi measured data, and the climatological aerosol and o3 data are provided as the inputs to a radiative transfer model for a clear sky
the omi algorithm is based on the toms surface uv algorithm with accuracies for a clear sky with snow and aerosol free cases of 7% and of the order of 10% at 380 nm at 305 nm, respectively
the omi algorithm employs the measured data at the satellite overpass time and lookup tables for the evaluation of the irradiance values at local solar noon

a comparison of the uv data from the omi and the gome-2 satellites over the date range of 1 june 2009 to 1 february 2021 is provided in figure 2. the total daily erythemal uv exposure and the daily erythemal maximum uv irradiance are provided as a comparison

some of the scatter in the data may be due to the changes in the cloud cover where the cloud cover for the omi data are determined at the afternoon time of the omi satellite, and the cloud cover for the gome-2 data are determined from satellite overpasses in the morning and in the afternoon remote sens

the process as described in the omi algorithm theoretical basis the omi does not cover the boundary layer of the atmosphere , which is the bottom layer of the troposphere
the omi surface algorithm was derived from the toms uv algorithm , and it can correct for aerosols when absorbing effects can be estimated, and there is no significant cloudiness
the process as described in the omi algorithm theoretical basis document uses lookup tables and either: cloud/non-absorbing aerosol correction or absorbing aerosol correction
the threshold values of ai must be 0.5 in order for the omi to apply a correction and when the ler is less than 0.15
errors in uv irradiance determination from the omi algorithm occur because omi does not distinguish between non-absorbing aerosols and thin clouds , resulting in overestimation
because the omi does not reach the boundary layer, this results in cloud correction underestimating the corresponding attenuation of the surface uv irradiance

it should be noted that the algorithm discussed above relates only to the uv surface product algorithm and does not include a discussion of the separate aerosol algorithms that omi also uses to monitor aerosols (omaeruv and omaero)

5. broadband uva irradiance and exposures from omi data omi uv satellite data products include discreet spectral irradiance measurements recorded as the satellite passes at a given site on the earth's surface once per day with the algorithm extrapolating to derive the local solar noon information
the omi algorithm also derives the local uv index and the daily erythemally weighted uv exposure

many studies have therefore utilized the omi spectral irradiance and o3 data to derive erythemally effective exposures and global surface uv index for a range of marine and surface sites at both high and low altitudes

isolated spectral data products derived from the omi solar noon time data may also be used to reconstruct the unweighted local surface uv irradiance in w m 2 (295 to 400 nm), the unweighted surface uvb irradiance in w m 2 (295 to 320 nm), or the surface uva in w m 2 (320 to 400 nm)
previous research reconstructed the unweighted surface uva irradiance at solar noon from the omi 310 nm, 324 nm and 380 nm data products

this reconstruction technique utilized a numerical integration of the spectral irradiance whereby the omi local spectral irradiance, i(310), i(324) and i(380) in units of w m 2 at 310 nm, 324 nm and 380 nm, respectively, were used to approximate the irradiance function at each given uv wavelength of the irradiance integral, euv according to a trapezoidal approximation (equation (1))

in calculating the integral, i(0) and i(n) are not typically one of the omi spectral irradiance data products i(305), i(310), i(324) or i(380), but rather a limiting point defining the desired uv waveband as in the case of previous research where i(0) was set at i(320) and i(n) at i(400)

in this approximation, the integral is assumed to not increase between 380 and 400 nm and the starting point i(320) is estimated as the linear function value of i( i) 10 nm from the omi spectral irradiance i(310), which provides equation (3)
in deriving the total irradiance, i( i) is evaluated assuming the irradiance interval varies linearly between the choice of i(0) and i(n) or each intermediary omi spectral irradiance

the omi total daily erythemal exposure is calculated from the information at the single satellite pass time and assumes the daily irradiance distribution follows a normal trend with no temporal variation in the sampled cloud cover fraction from the cloud cover measurement times
a similar technique has recently been applied to determine the total daily uva exposure in kj m 2 under cloud-free atmospheric conditions using the daily omi spectral irradiance data product

this research initially reconstructed the solar noon (maximum daily) uva irradiance (320 to 400 nm) from the omi spectral irradiance i(310), i(324) and i(380) as described in the previous section to derive the daily surface uva exposure integral assuming a normally distributed exposure profile between sunrise and sunset

as the total available uva (320 to 400 nm) at the earth's surface is 20 times greater than the available uvb , daily uva exposure integrals evaluated from the omi spectral noon time irradiance are much higher than the spectrally weighted erythema uv

7. comparison of omi uva with ground-based data a series of research papers have reported on the comparison of the omi-derived atmospheric o3 and the erythemal uv with ground-based measurements (for example, )
the research that has compared the uva spectral irradiance from the omi platform to ground-based spectral measurements is for the omi-measured uvb wavelengths of 324 nm and 380 nm
generally, the omi data have a positive bias compared to the ground-based data at these wavelengths
this positive bias is attributed to the influence of aerosol absorption not taken into account by the omi algorithm
in an urban environment, the omi spectral uva irradiance at 324 nm and 380 nm were compared with the ground-based measurements from a brewer spectrophotometer
in this research, the omi values overestimate the ground-based data by 17% and 13%, respectively
other researchers have compared the omi uva irradiance at 324 nm with that from a brewer spectroradiometer with an omi-positive bias of 8.7% for cloud-free days

in the uva, previous research has compared the 2009 omi spectral solar noon uva satellite data for 324 and 380 nm as well as at the uvb wavelength of 310 nm with the ground-based measurements for a southern hemisphere relatively unpolluted subtropical site

a comparison at a southern hemisphere site (27.6 s) of the broadband uva irradiance evaluated for cloudfree days in 2009 from the omi data at 310 nm, 324 nm and 380 nm to the ground-based uva radiometer data provided an r2 of 0.86

this research was then extended to a 12 year period from 2004 to 2016 to evaluate and compare the uva broadband irradiance evaluated from the 310 nm, 324 nm and 380 nm omi spectral irradiance to the ground-based uva radiometer measurements for a subtropical site
the results show that the uva solar noon irradiance can be evaluated with an rrmse of 18% or less from the omi remote sens

the instrumentation on satellite platforms measuring in the uva waveband has been providing solar noon spectral irradiance data at 324 nm and 380 nm since october 2004. this narrowband irradiance data set from omi has been employed to evaluate the broadband solar noon uva irradiance, along with the calculation of the uva waveband total daily exposures

9. conclusions the unique strength of the omi and gome-2 satellite data is the provision of longterm data series on a global scale that are generally on a daily basis provided the satellite instrumentation is operational

the advantage of the omi data is that it provides a longerterm uv data series dating back to october 2004, whereas the gome-2 data series dates back to june 2009. additionally, the omi data provides the spectral irradiances at two uva wavelengths and two uvb wavelengths

furthermore, the gome-2 data incorporates the cloud data at two times of the day, namely from a satellite morning overpass and a satellite afternoon overpass, whereas the omi algorithm uses the cloud information from a single satellite overpass
both the omi and gome-2 data are freely available for downloading provided there is acknowledgment in any resulting works of the source of the data
acknowledgments: the authors acknowledge the omi mission scientists and associated nasa personnel for the production of the data used in this research effort
satellite observations applied in this study is the aura omi (omi) level 2 so2 total column product (omso2 v003)(li et al 2013, 2020)
omi is a near-uv/visible nadir solar backscatter ccd spectrometer on aura satellite (levelt et al 2006)

it has been observing aerosols and trace gases since 2004. omi provides a nearly global coverage in one day, while the pixel size increases slowly from 13 × 24 km2 at nadir to 28 × 150 km2 at the outermost swath angle (levelt et al 2006)

2.2.1. pixel-averaging method for the generation of a higher resolution satellite dataset, pixelaveraging method provided by (fioletov et al 2011, 2013, 2016) is applied to process omi satellite observations: a grid set with 0.02◦ spatial resolution is established around the power plants, the time range is set at 1-year, and the averaging radius is set at 18 km
as the reference point goes, we get the result of sliding t-test

it has the advantage of using twice-daily radiosonde soundings over most weather stations if the maximum virtual potential t coincides with the mmlh and thus has been adopted by many studies to estimate the mmlh thereafter (eg seidel et al 2010; li et al 2020)
the second merra (merra-2) is a nasa atmospheric reanalysis that begins in 1980 with the enhanced use of satellite observations (gelaro et al 2017)

the reanalysis pblh is estimated based on the ri method with a critical value of 0.25 in era5 (c3s 2017) and the total eddy diffusion coefficient of heat with a threshold value of 2 m2 s21 in merra-2 (eg mcgrath-spangler and molod 2014; davy and esau 2014)

the monthly means of hourly averaged pblh, surface sensible heat flux (shfx; w m22), surface latent heat flux (lhfx; w m22), surface skin t (ts; k), 2-m air t (t2m; k), 2-m dewpoint t (td2m; k), 2-m specific humidity (q2m; kg kg21), 2-m air rh (rh2m; %), and lifting condensational level (lcl; m or hpa), were analyzed for merra-2 (1980-2019) and era5 (1979-2019)
the lcl is provided by merra-2 as the height of lcl (m)
for both merra-2 and era5, rh2m is not provided and so is calculated using t2m and td2m based on the equation in dutton (1976)

the monthly means of daily mean pblh for the 10 members were analyzed for the period 1979-2019. we also used the ri method to estimate the pblh at 6-hourly intervals for the period 1980-2019 (referred to as the merra-2-ri; table 2) based on the 6-hourly 3d atmospheric instantaneous and hourly averaged 2d near-surface fields for air t, humidity, gph, and wind speed from the merra-2 output

columns 4-10 (the corresponding pblh related surface variables): shfx is sensible heat flux (w m22), lhfx is latent heat flux (w m22), plcl is the pressure at lifting condensation level (hpa) from era5, zlcl is the height at lifting condensation level (m) from merra-2, ts is surface skin t (k), t2m is 2-m surface air t (k), td2m is 2-m surface dewpoint t (k), q2m is 2-m surface specific humidity (g kg21), and rh2m is 2-m surface relative humidity (%)

our results suggest that the reanalysis pblh estimate might be more reliable in era5 than in merra-2. the reanalysis pblh is estimated based on the ri method in era5 and the total eddy diffusion coefficient of heat in merra-2 (eg mcgrath-spangler and molod 2014; davy and esau 2014)

11. regional-mean interannual variations in pblhmean anomaly (in green) and three pblh-related variables (in red): sensible heat (shfx; w m22), surface skin t (ts; k), and 2-m relative humidity (rh2m; %), for (left) era5 and (right) merra-2 averaged between 608s and 608n for the period 1979-2019. the correlation coefficient (r) and its significance (p value) and sample size (n) are shown within each panel
our pblh estimates using the ri method from the merra-2-ri are much smaller than the pblhs from the merra-2 and comparable to the era5 estimate
also, systematic biases were documented in the merra-2 pblh, particularly at nighttime (eg mcgrath-spangler and molod 2014; svensson and lindvall 2015; dang et al 2016; davy 2018; zhou 2021)

furthermore, our validations using the radiosonde data show the era5 pblh is closer to the observations than merra-2. if this is the case, rising pblh is likely more widespread spatially than that seen in merra-2. our results indicate large discrepancies among different pblh datasets, which are likely due to the differences in spatial resolution (point measurements versus coarse-resolution grid averaged data), observational uncertainties, and deficiencies in modeling the surface radiative forcing, surface energy partitioning, and pbl mixing

2.1. raw measurements and data sources 2.1.1. merra-2 t and humidity reanalysis t and humidity are proven to have close relationships with the spread and control of covid-19

our data collection includes reanalyzed t and humidity of merra and version 2 (merra-2) to provide historic and present casting values for the researchers and decision-makers to estimate and predict the spreading trends and patterns of the pandemic
the merra-2 provides data dating back to 1980 with a spatial resolution of ~50 km

our data collection introduces imerg (imerg) as a potential related data source for the study of covid-19. the imerg precipitation estimation is a satellite-observation-based rainfall measurement that provides global coverage and spatial resolution of 10 km and temporal resolution of 30 min

, to accomplish their specific study related to covid-19. detailed information is shown in table 1. 2.1.4. aura-omi air pollution observation air pollutants such as no2 are important indicators of economic and influence the mortality of covid-19
the omi (omi) flies on the national aeronautics and space administration's earth observing system aura satellite launched in july 2004
the spatial resolution of omi is 25 km, covering the globe once a day

the omi measures criteria pollutants such as no, o3, no2 and so2. the us environmental protection agency (epa) has designated these atmospheric constituents as posing serious threats to human health and agricultural productivity
the spatiotemporal distribution of omi data will dynamically change with covid-19 spreads
for example, the team is working to automatically correspond omi no2 data with administration shapefiles and to provide country and county level no2 information to the communities

in fact, one of the improvements in the aeronet version 2.0 data is the inclusion of a dynamic spectral and spatial satellite and model estimation of the surface albedo, substituting the static assumption of a spectrally, temporally and spatially green world in version 1.0. for land surface covers, the lie-ross model was adopted, where the bidirectional reflectance distribution function (brdf) parameters are taken from the modis ecotype generic brdf models for vegetation, snow and ice

in order to check the effect of this procedure in the rf calculation, the surface albedo was calculated using modis product mcd43a3. these datasets provide the model parameters fiso, fvol y fgeo computed for the modis bands 1-7 (645, 859, 469, 555, 1240, 1640, 2130 nm), as well as for three broad bands (0.3-0.7 m, 0.7-5.0 m, and 0.3-5.0 m)

these products are stored on 1-min and coarser resolution equal-angle grids and each image is retrieved daily and represent the best brdf possible based on 16 days interval of modis atmospherically corrected data with the day of interest emphasized

figure 5 shows the surface albedo obtained from the modis product (red dots) and provided by aeronet (black squares) for the 26 june 2013. since the aeronet values are also derived from modis model, a good agreement was expected within the shared spectral region (440-1020 nm), as it occurs, with a possible explanation for these discrepancies due to the averaging procedure followed to extract the information from the modis image

the comparison of the linear extrapolation from the longest aeronet wavelength to a zero albedo at 4 m (black line) shows some discrepancy with the modis-derived values at longest wavelengths (1.24, 1.64, and 2.13 m)

3.1. datasets 3.1.1. gpm imerg gpm (gpm) is an international satellite mission, carrying advanced radar and radiometer systems to observe global precipitation; it was launched by national aeronautics and space administration (nasa) and the japanese aerospace exploration agency (jaxa) in february 2014 (hufman et al 2015)
as the successor of the trmm (trmm), gpm enables more precise and reliable rainfall estimations
gpm consists of a core observation satellite and eight constellation satellites (yong et al 2015)
each constellation provides microwave sensor data for gpm to achieve better global coverage
the gpm products provide precipitation data every 30 min with a spatial resolution of 0.1 × 0.1, covering the global 60n-60s region
the first dual frequency precipitation radar (dpr) was introduced to obtain precipitation from ka band (35.5 ghz) and ku band (13.6 ghz) (iguchi et al 2018)

the highly sensitive mode detection signal used by the dpr can better monitor light intensity precipitation and falling snow, which account for a large proportion of the total precipitation at middle and high latitudes (hou et al 2014)
the multichannel gpm microwave imager (gmi) includes 13 channels, ranging from 10 to 183 ghz, which help gpm to increase its sensitivity to obtain liquid precision, light precision, and ice particles

among all existing satellite precipitation products, gpm is considered to be the most reliable and accurate satellite and has been widely used by a variety of fields (sharifi et al 2016; skofronick-jackson et al 2017; tang et al 2020; wang et al 2017)
gpm products are widely used in extreme precipitation, disaster prediction, and hydrological simulations (yuan et al 2018)
this study selected the imerg (imerg) product to investigate the temporal and spatial distributions of precipitation over the tp
the imerg product uses diferent sensors from diferent constellation satellites to detect precipitation
imerg adopts the algorithm of collaborative calibration, and merges and interpolates microwave precipitation of all satellites (ie its constellation satellites)
imerg has been widely used to study topographical precipitation (geng et al 2017)
with its resolution of 0.1 × 0.1, the gpm is just able to meet the optimal configuration of terrain and precipitation

in par ticular, the gpm ofers advantages over other satellites in two aspects: (1) the coverage ranges from 60s to 60n, which covers all regions of the tp; (2) the precipitation radar has been upgraded to two frequencies, which adds sensitivity to light precipitation and snowfall (hamada and takayabu, 2016; qin et al 2014)
to match the resolution of the gpm, obtain the main terrain change, and avoid the influence of trivial terrain, the 90 m resolution was resampled to a 0.1 resolution using the nearest neighbor method
the data of meteorological stations used in this study originated from the china meteorological administration (cma)
the daily data provided by cma is based on beijing time, which ranges from 20:00 of the previous day to 20:00 of the present day (corresponding to 12:00 to 12:00 in utc time), while gpm uses utc time
therefore, time conversion was performed according to the half day data of each station to obtain daily precipitation data consistent with gpm data in a daily time range
gpm imerg from january 1, 2015, to december 31, 2018, was used to estimate the annual average precipitation
based on 158 gauged data, the quality of the imerg product was evaluated
5.1. evaluation of gpm precipitation products the validity of gpm precipitation data is verified via comparison with the observation results of gauge stations
first, the annual average precipitation of 158 stations was calculated from 2015 to 2018, as well as the annual average precipitation of gpm for corresponding times and locations
the precipitation quality of the gpm was estimated by fig
the results show that the coeficient of certainty of gpm and gauge stations is r2 = 0.87, with a linear slope of 0.95, which indicates obvious consistency between gpm and gauge stations

because of the uncertainty of satellite monitoring in high-altitude areas, the precipitation data of 14 meteorological stations above 4000 m were compared with the gpm precipitation data (as shown in fig

the average annual precipitation of these 14 meteorological stations is 59.3-832.4 mm and the certainty coeficient is r 2 = 0.68. this shows that gpm can explain 68% of the variation of precipitation in highaltitude areas
therefore, gpm satellite precipitation meets the required research needs
in addition, the gpm precipitation in arid areas, located in the northern tp and the tarim basin margin adjacent to the tp, was verified by 11 gauge stations (fig

the results show that the pre cipitation according to gpm is slightly lower than that of meteorological stations in the adjacent areas of the northern tp and the southern edge of the tarim basin; however, the precipitation according to gpm is slightly higher than that of weather stations in the adjacent areas of the tarim basin and the tianshan mountains
however, the precipitation change trend found by gpm is consistent with that found by meteorological station data, which can be used to study climate change trends

based on the high-resolution satellite precipitation product gpm, this paper presents the influence of tp topography on the spatial dis tribution of precipitation
in the himalayas, the conclusion is the same as that of previous studies using pr (pr) data (bookhagen and burbank, 2006; maussion et al 2014; shrestha et al 2012)

geng et al (2017) studied the relationship between precipitation and elevation in the qilian mountains using gpm imerg and found that precipitation change has obvious elevation control characteristics
compared with trmm data, gpm provides wider coverage and higher accuracy
however, because of the short time span of gpm, the grid sampling of gpm dpr data (with its more accurate resolution than trmm pr) is insuficient
if only the gpm dpr data is used, the spatial pattern of precipitation remains unclear (tang et al 2018)
therefore, gpm imerg data is widely used at present
compared with trmm pr, the ability of gpm imerg data to capture precipitation is weak
for example, trmm pr clearly captures the second peak of precipitation in the central himalayas (78e-88e) (bookhagen and burbank, 2006; shrestha et al 2012)
gpm imerg also captured this feature (fig
with regard to regional coverage, trmm pr can only cover 38n, which cannot cover the entire tp

data: merra-2 and era5 two reanalysis datasets were used in the eof analysis: data from the merra, version 2 (merra-2; gelaro et al 2017) produced by nasa's global modeling and assimilation office (gmao) and the fifth-generation european center for medium-range weather forecasts (ecmwf) reanalysis (era5; copernicus climate change service 2017a)

the spatial resolution of the merra-2 data is 0.6258 3 0.58, while the resolution of the era5 data is 0.288 3 0.288. our usage of these reanalysis products was motivated by the amount of observed atmospheric data they assimilate
it should be noted that the merra-2 reanalysis assimilates no land surface observations, while the era5 reanalysis is produced with satellite-based sm data
thus, the land variables in merra-2 are likely dependent on the land surface model used to produce the reanalysis product
we first carried out eof analysis using merra-2 data as input, then repeated the analysis using era5 data in order to corroborate the patterns revealed by the merra-2 analysis
merra-2 data were obtained at the finest available temporal resolution for each variable (1 or 6 h) and averaged to obtain monthly mean values for the entire 37-yr period
merra-2 and era5 precipitation (gmao 2015a; copernicus climate change service 2017b) and root-zone sm (gmao 2015b) were used in this study
merra-2 latent heat flux (lh) and sensible heat flux (sh; gmao 2015b) were also analyzed
only merra-2 provides root-zone sm (defined as an average of sm over the first meter below the surface) as a standard variable
the merra-2 sm variable used is the ground wetness fraction, a unitless measure of relative saturation, which is 0 for completely dry soil and 1 for completely saturated soil

additionally, the proxies we chose, modis vis, lidar tree height and agb, although widely used in vod evaluation studies (fan et al 2019; liu et al 2011; rodrguez-fernandez et al 2018), cannot be considered as truth (li et al 2020a)

nevertheless, in spite of their limitations, we think the chosen proxies are relatively complementary in this study to evaluate vod retrievals as (i) correlation with modis vis could be regarded as a criterion more pertinent for short vegetation canopies

smos-ic has the main following features: i) independent of auxiliary data: contrary to the official algorithms no ecmwf modelled sm data or modis lai products are used in smos-ic; only ecmwf t is used currently (fernandez-moran et al 2017a; li et al 2020a); ii) relative to the baseline smos algorithms, it is simpler and avoids uncertainties and errors associated with inconsistent auxiliary datasets and decision trees which are adopted to characterize the pixel heterogeneity in the other smos algorithms (wigneron et al 2018); iii) it is based on new maps of model parameters for soil roughness and vegetation scattering effects (fernandez-moran et al 2017a; parrens et al 2016)
the amsr2, which was launched by jaxa on may 17, 2012, is an improved successor of amsr-e onboard gcom-w1. amsr2 has similar x
li et al orbits, bands and local overpass times (1:30 am for descending orbit and 1:30 pm for ascending orbit) as amsr-e (imaoka et al 2012)

in this study we used amsr2 vod products for the descending orbits computed from two reference algorithms (i) lprm (land parameter retrieval model; owe et al 2008) and (ii) lpdr (land parameter data record; du et al 2017b)
these amsr2 vod products have the same sample resolution of 25 km and are briefly described in the following
in the present study, we used the amsr2 vod product retrieved from lprm v5 (owe et al 2008), as the latest version (v6) is not publicly available (van der schalie et al 2017)

the lprm v5 retrieval process used amsr2 spatial-resolution-matched tb (l1sgrtbr) as input tb data, and the input land surface t was retrieved separately from the amsr2 ka-band (36.5 ghz; holmes et al 2009)
here, we used the descending vod products from amsr2 c1-, c2-, x-band (vrije universiteit amsterdam and nasa gsfc, 2014)

in comparison to the previous version (jones et al 2010), v2 has advantages in both temporal coverage and retrieval accuracy, and the main refinements and updates include: i) extended time period from amsr-e (june 19, 2002) to amsr2 (december 31, 2018) by empirically calibrating the amsr2 multi-frequency tb retrieval algorithm on the same channel as amsr-e; ii) refined amsr2 estimation of the daily maximum and minimum surface air t by considering terrain and latitude effects (du et al 2015); iii) improved sm retrieval by using a dynamic selection of vegetation-scattering albedos (du et al 2016)

specifically, unlike liu et al (2011), which harmonized all observations to amsr-e's high-quality c-vod, this product is a frequency-specific vod dataset as different frequencies carry valuable specific information suitable for various applications (teubner et al 2019)

vodca combined vod observations from amsr2, windsat, amsr-e, trmm (tmi), and special sensor microwave/ imager (ssm/i) into long-term vod datasets at c-band (period 2002-2018), x-band (1997-2018), and ku-band (1987-2017)

the biases between the vod values retrieved from different sensors were eliminated by scaling them to amsr-e vod using a new implementation of the cumulative distribution function matching technique; further detailed information about the retrieval algorithm are given in moesinger et al (2020)
we mainly use modis daily data () studies, this is where snowfall occurs and glaciers are located

we mainly use modis daily data with a special resolution of 0.5 and 1 km, as shown in table 1. the latest modis data collection () with a special resolution of 0.5 and 1 km, as shown in error! the modis instrument products do not generate data in the presence of clouds in order to minimize the e ect of missing data under these conditions
we combined the data recovered from the terra and aqua satellites, by means of the daily pixel by pixel comparison to replace the failed data or overcast sky
this was observed during the pass of the terra satellite but not by the aqua satellite and vice versa
this is because these satellites have the modis instrument on board and pass through the studied area daily, but, at di erent times, increase the probability of taking cloud-free observations
for example, when only using terra (mod10a1), data were retrieved for 69% of the analyzed time period
however, when combined with data retrieved from aqua (myd10a1), the cloud-free data increased to 83%

the main conclusions of the study are summarized as follows: 1. for the validation of three imerg 0.5 h products, with threshold increasing, detection capability of three products weakens at each gauge and each date while the diurnal variation of pod and csi at the basin-scale becomes more significant
imerg-f performs better than imerg-e in terms of cpi

2. for the comparison between imerg v06 and v05 daily products, in terms of the basin-scale, imerg v06 shows better performance than v05 on pod increasing under partial thresholds, pcc enhancement at month and day cumulative scales, rmse reduction in 7 of 12 months and underestimation improvement in the relatively dry and cold months
3. for the comparison between imerg v06 and tmpa 3b43 monthly products, imerg v06 has advantages over tmpa in many aspects

for study of long-term pwv trends, we used merra -2 (merra, version 2) and airs (airs) pwv data during 2003-2018. the merra-2 data is the latest atmospheric reanalysis of the modern satellite era produced by nasa's global modeling and assimilation office (gmao)

on the other hand, the airs instrument onboard on nasa's aqua satellite.2 is launched into earth-orbit on may 4, 2002. the airs instrument along with its partner microwave instrument, advanced msu (amsu-a), observes and characterizes the entire atmospheric column from the surface to the top of the atmosphere in terms of surface emissivity and t, atmospheric t and humidity profiles, cloud amount and height, and the 1 ://(ir) region is from 3.7 to 15.4 m

the airs ir spatial resolution is 13.5 km at nadir from the 705.3 km orbit and the vis/nir spatial resolution is 2.3 km.3 the satellite orbits or covers the same area on earth two times per day in descending (north pole to south pole) and ascending orbits (south pole to north pole) at 1:30 am and 1:30 pm local time, respectively
using airs data during 2003-2008, dessler et al 2008 reported that as a result of the increasing global average t, specific humidity is increasing over most of the troposphere

the moderate resolution imaging spectroradiometer (modis) data from both, the terra and aqua satellites, were employed in this analysis
to assess land-cover changes in this work, the modis vi products (mod13), that provide spatial and temporal time series comparisons of global vegetation conditions, were utilized

specifically, the mod13a2.006 product (from terra mod13 series) was used that provides two vegetation indexes data, namely, the normalized diference vegetation index (ndvi) and the evi, that has been operational from 2000 to present (didan etal
moreover, the mod16a2.006 data product (from terra mod16 series) was also used for the et analysis, that has been operational from 2001 to present (running etal
the mod16 series output is based on the logic of the penman-monteith equation and uses daily meteorological reanalysis data as well as 8-day remotely sensed vegetation property dynamics as inputs

here, we also used the third data product from modis, which is the terra and aqua combined modis land-cover type (mcd12q1) version 6, which has been operational from 2001 to 2019 (friedl and sulla-menashe 2015)
this data product provides global land-cover types and is derived using supervised classifications of modis terra and aqua reflectance data
for terra et (fig.3a), the overall lowest and highest recorded et is illustrated during djf and jja, respectively
both fldas (fig.3b) and gldas (fig.3c) et products achieve a general consistency with terra data

for terra evi (fig.3g), the highest recorded evi is during mam in the north and during djf in the nile delta, while the lowest recorded evi is during djf in the north and during son in the southern area
there is a consistent negative correlation observed in the northern mediterranean region between precipitation and terra et (fig.4e)

there is moderate correlation between terra et and et fldas (fig.4g), and terra et and et gldas (fig.4i) as observed in the northern mediterranean region, while there are high correlations among ssm and sm fldas (fig.4h), ssm and sm gldas (fig.4j), et fldas and et gldas (fig.4k), and sm gldas and sm fldas (fig.4l)
in this study, land-cover change detection was performed for mediterranean region during the 2009-2018 period using mcd12q1.006 modis land cover type yearly global 500m data

greece appears to have dominant variations for precipitation (fig.7c) over the period compared to other selected countries with minimum observed in october 2012 and the maximum observed in november 2012. for et observed from modis (fig.7d), it has significant variation for greece where the lowest is recorded in june 2012 and the highest is recorded in june 2018. all the other countries seem to have similar variations over the period

7 time-series of ssm (in mm), evi, precipitation (in mm), and terra et (in 10-5mm/s) over six locations within the mediterranean region from 2010 to 2018 from the climatology plots (fig.3), we observed that even though data were collected from diferent sources such as fldas and gldas, there is apparent coherency for the same variables such as et and sm

however, when comparing model results with observational data, it could be noticed that seasonal averages from terra satellite for et were lower as compared to the seasonal averages retrieved from fldas and gldas

the data from each source, namely, terra satellite, fldas, and gldas, were aggregated over the decade 2009-2018. a possible explanation for the diference in values could be the diference in temporal resolution of these data sources
the terra satellite records real-time observations only once in 16days as compared to the fldas and gldas data which record observations throughout the day in 15min time intervals

et values in the region of interest would keep on changing as the day progresses, which would explain the diference between the seasonal averages of terra satellite retrievals and the models (fldas/gldas)

as access to ground observations in the region of interest was lacking, the results could not be validated to check whether the terra satellite data were underestimating, or the models were overestimating the et values
the gldas-2.1 is revised with upgraded models forced by a combination of gdas, disaggregated gpcp, and agrmet radiation data sets
the ancillary input data of the proposed approach comprise modis lst and modis vi data, including the evi and ndvi products
the daily lst was provided by the modis/terra land surface t/emissivity (mod11a1) (wan et al 2015), which is posted on the global 1 km sin grid
the 16-day evi and ndvi products were provided by the modis/terra vegetation indices product (mod13a2) (didan, 2015)
this paper also uses mod09a1 data (vermote, 2015), which is a surface reflectance product of modis/terra

3.2. merra-2 the merra, version 2 (merra-2) is an atmospheric reanalysis designed to provide an intermediate dataset and bridge between the first merra reanalysis and the project's long-term goal of producing a coupled earth system reanalysis
merra-2 provides data from 1980. it uses the latest v5 goddard earth observing system model (goes) data assimilation with an updated grid to point statistical interpolation system

merra-2 incorporates system changes and fundamental developments in modeling and data assimilation, including (1) assimilation of aerosol observations that can interact with atmospheric radiative processes; (2) constraining mass conservation even with the analysis of h2o, allowing a global balance between evaporation and precipitation; (3) use of a cube sphere to reduce the effect of grid point singularities at the pole, allowing for improved polar circulation; (4) an updated radiative transfer model to permit the assimilation of data from many more instruments than could have been included in merra; and (5) inclusion of new observational forcing for the land model to provide more stable land feedback processes
merra-2 assimilates bias-corrected aerosol optical depth (aod) from the moderate resolution imaging spectroradiometer and the avhrr instruments
moreover, merra-2 assimilates (non-bias-corrected) aod from the multiangle imaging spectrora- diometer over bright surfaces and aod from aerosol robotic network sunphotometer stations

one of the advantages of merra-2 data is their ability to provide detailed information on how the anthropogenic component of aerosols, and thus radiative forcing, has changed during the modern satellite era, as well as its interaction with the circulation and the climate at large

the merra, version 2 (merra-2), from the global modeling and assimilation office (gmao) at nasa is a state-of-the-art atmospheric reanalysis that assimilates a vast number of in situ and remote sensing observations (gelaro et al 2017; gmao 2015)
the catchment-lsm is used in the merra-2 reanalysis system, which provides soil moisture estimates at a 0.58 latitude 3 0.6258 longitude resolution
merra-2 has been used in previous flash drought analysis (koster et al 2019), which provides confidence in using it as the reference data in our evaluation
the noah-lsm implemented within the nasa land information system (lis) is used in the nca-ldas simulations, which provide soil moisture estimates at a 0.1258 latitude 3 0.1258 longitude resolution
it should be noted that the cpc unified gauge-based analysis and merged analysis of precipitation are also used to bias correct precipitation in merra-2 before it feeds the catchment-lsm
climatology of flash drought occurrence figure 3 shows flash drought occurrence based on merra-2, nca-ldas, and the two cesm2 simulations
both merra-2 and nca-ldas suggest frequent flash drought events in the central, western, and southeastern united states

nca-ldas shows more frequent flash drought events in western and eastern canada, which are not present in merra-2. this can be associated with the reported issues of the nca-ldas forcing, which blends disparate precipitation sources in the united states and canada (blankenship et al 2018)
it should be noted that merra-2, nca-ldas, and cesm2 are at different spatial resolutions

on the other hand, the evident difference between merra-2 and nca-ldas suggests that land surface models and input observations used in those assimilation systems may play a more important role in simulated soil moisture dynamics

in the current study measured bc mass concentrations over ahmedabad and gurushikhar are compared with the merra version 2 (merra-2) model (gelaro et al 2017) simulated bc mass concentrations for the years 2015-2016 (mean of monthly values) (fig
the merra-2 model is based on the goddard earth observing system (geos) atmospheric data assimilation
the merra-2 model uses a cubed-sphere horizontal discretization at a latitude-longitude resolution of 0.5o x 0.625o and 72-hybrid-eta levels up to 0.01 mbar (gelaro et al 2017)

the aerosols in merra-2 model are simulated with a radiatively coupled version of the goddard chemistry, aerosol, radiation and transport (gocart) (colarco et al 2010), and simulates dust, sea salt, black carbon, organic carbon (oc) and so4
the merra-2 aerosol analysis is based on the goddard aerosol assimilation system (randles et al 2017)
the merra-2 aerosol assimilation system was found to show considerable skill in simulating several observed aerosol properties including surface concentrations (buchard et al 2017)
the merra-2 simulated mass concentrations were found to show a high degree of correlation with the observed surface mass concentrations for the entire year (r 0.69) (buchard et al 2017)
the merra-2 model-observation comparison evaluation also showed that the assimilation cannot correct for all the model deficiencies, for example, the missing emissions (buchard et al 2017)

the bc mass concentrations simulated by merra-2 over ahmedabad, an urban source region and gurushikhar, a high-altitude, background location are similar
the merra-2 and echam6 model simulated features are quite similar to those reported earlier based on gocart and mozart model simulations over kanpur, the igp and all india

the lack/absence of proper aerosol emissions is the main cause for underestimation of bc mass is confirmed by the fact, as both - a fine resolution model (merra2) and a coarse resolution model (echam6) produce similar results

10. seasonal and spatial variation in bc mass concentrations simulated by merra-2 model for the years 2015-16 over the indian subcontinent during (a) winter, (b) premonsoon, (c) monsoon and (d) postmonsoon

further, the single scattering albedo (ssa = ratio of aerosol scattering to extinction) of aerosols was higher than observations because bc aerosols were underestimated in merra-2 (ramachandran et al 2020)
this concurs with the finding that though merra-2 generally compares well with observations, however, deficiencies in the model occur due to missing aerosol emissions (buchard et al 2017)

it was also pointed out that better agreement of merra-2 model results with observations were seen in rural areas since urban areas are influenced by high, localised emissions that are not representative of grid estimated by merra-2 (buchard et al 2017)

the lack of inter-annual variability in model simulated bc mass concentration occurs mainly because of lack of appropriate emissions and their inter-annual variability, and not due to meteorology as assimilated meteorological parameters are used in merra-2. these results on model-observation comparison of bc mass are also consistent with the findings of shindell et al (2013) and koch et al (2009) who reported that global and regional models tend to signifi cantly underestimate (by a factor of 2 to >10) the bc mass concentrations over asia

the bc mass concentrations simulated by two models - merra-2, a ifner resolution model (0.5o x 0.625o), and echam6-ham2, a coarser resolution model (1.8o x 1.8o), are significantly underestimated by 2-5 times over the urban ahmedabad than observations, though the models capture the seasonal cycle of winter high and monsoon low in bc mass
the magnitude of bc mass concentrations simulated by merra-2 and echam6 over ahmedabad and gurushikhar are quite similar

the rest of the data (ie precipitation, wind speed, and solar radiation) were retrieved from the merra version 2 database, known as merra-2
merra-2, which is part of nasa's atmospheric reanalysis database, offers global gridded meteorological data of several variables, also free of charge

merra-2 is the updated version of reanalysis data in the modern satellite era produced by the global modeling-assimilation office (gmao)- nasa (gelaro et al 2017), using the goddard earth observing system, version 5 (geos-5) (molod et al 2015)
in addition, merra-2 provides aerosol product that fig

assimilates a variety of aod datasets from different observation sources, such as the advanced very high-resolution radiometer (avhrr) before 1999, non-bias-corrected aods retrieved from multi-angle imaging spectroradiometer (misr) in the years 2000-2014, earth observing system (eos) era satellites after 2000, aeronet since 1999, and modis (collection 5.1 for both the aqua and terra sensors) since 2000 (bibi et al 2016; buchard et al 2017; gelaro et al 2017; kahn et al 2010; remer et al 2005)

a summary of the merra-2 modeling process and more elaborated information of merra-2 aerosols data can be found in gelaro et al (2017) and ) datasets at a resolution of 62.5 km longitude by 50 km latitude during 1980-2018 were used in this research

the modis sensor onboard the aqua and terra platforms observes the earth at different spectral wavelengths including 36 bands between 410 and 1450 nm with a daily temporal resolution and spatial resolution of 1 km, 0.5 km, and 0.25 km

modis provides two aod daily products, aqua/myd-04 around 13:30 lt and terra/mod-04 around 11:30 lt, starting in late june 2002 and 2000, respectively, both as collection 6.1 (c6.1) and level 2 (l2), with a 10 km spatial resolution
the expected errors (ee) of the l2 modis aod product are about 0.15 aod 0.05 over land and 0.05 aod 0.03 over ocean (levy et al 2013)

more detailed description about aod, ae and ee of modis l2 c6.1 aerosol products can be found in , two aod datasets were used, dark _target _deep_blue_aod_550_combined (dtdb) retrieved from mod-04 and myd-04 at 550 nm during the years 2001-2018 and 2003-2018, respectively
due to the precision of aeronet , long-term instantaneous aod of 9 aeronet sites were downloaded from , modis and mmm

in order to reduce the number of missing cells from the satellite instruments and produce a near-daily dataset, the dtdb aods of both tera and aqua at 550 nm were merged (named as modis aod) during 2003-2018, while the aod in 2001 and 2002 was represented by dtdb/aqua aod

the modis and merra-2 aods at high spatial resolution (10 km 10 km and 50 km 62.5 km, respectively) were resampled to 100 km spatial grid, using the nearest neighbor interpolation technique (parker et al 1983) to overlap the pixels of each other, and to match the full field of aeronet view

furthermore, to confirm the reliability of aod assessment and better compare the results of the aod analysis, a merged aod product of merra-2 and modis, named as merra-2 modis merged aod (mmm), was generated on daily time series during 2001-2018. similar to our recent work (yousefi et al 2020), the mmm was generated using combination method

the detailed methodology of the mmm product is based on the following steps: 1) the modis dbdt aod retrievals at a spatial resolution of 10 km were resampled to 100 km using nearest neighbor interpolation algorithm prior to be combined with merra-2 aod
2) the merra-2 aod retravels at a spatial resolution of 62.5 km longitude by 50 km latitude were also resample to 100 km using the same method
3) modis and merra-2 aod grids were combined on daily based
in the mmm, missing pixels in modis data were represented by merra-2 aod values
4) modis, merra-2 and mmm were then averaged as a monthly series in order to be used in further processes in the current study
the 550 nm aod data from the 9 aeronet sites were then used to evaluate the performance of the modis, mmm and merra-2 aods

to ensure the accuracy of aod validation, instantaneous aeronet aod observations within 6 h were averaged as the hourly mean aod, and then as the monthly mean aod, to compared with the aod of mmm, modis and merra-2. the retrieval errors of these datasets are calculated using the pearson correlation coefficient , the relative mean bias , the mean-absolute-error and root-mean-square error , the fractional-gross-error , the mean-fractional-error , and the index of agreement as follows: pn oi omi m r qffipffiffiffiffiiffif1fiffiffiffiffiffiffiffifpfiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffififififififififififififi;fififififififififfiffiffiffiffi (1) in1oi o2 in1oi o2 1 xn n i1 mae j mi oij; n i1 sffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffifffiiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffiffi rmse 1 xn mi oi2; rmb m = o ; fge 2 xn mi n i1 mi oi oi mfe 2 n xn jmi oij i1 mi oi 100 ; 100 ; (2) (3) (4) (5) (6) ioa 1 p p in1joi in1oi mi2 mj joi mj2 100 (7) where n is the total number of pairs of observed (o, ie aeronet) and modeled or satellite (m, ie modis, merra-2, mmm) values

based on monthly time series data, long-period trend of the modis, merra-2 and mmm aods was obtained using the least-square linear regression - a technique globally used for time series analysis (dahutia et al 2018; klingmller et al 2016; ma et al 2019; pozzer et al 2015)
missing cells from modis may produce errors in long-term trend
therefore, to assure the accuracy of the trend assessment, each grid cell for the modis aod was required to have at least 70% of the monthly data

the ae470-870 and aod550 retrievals from daily data of merra-2 were used to classify the aerosol into different types, using the relationship between ae470-870 and aod550 - a technique widely implemented by previous researchers in different regions (bibi et al 2016; boiyo et al 2018; kaskaoutis et al 2007; rupakheti et al 2019)

the current research presents a comprehensive assessment of the aod trend in the em region during the past 39 years (1980-2018) based on the merra-2 reanalysis aod dataset and the satellite's aod retrievals from modis v6.1/terra and aqua during 2001-2018 and 2003-2018, respectively
in addition, a new daily aod product was generated based on combination of modis and merra-2 aod

aod observations from 9 aeronet sites were used to assess the performance of the aod of modis, merra-2, and mmm on regional scales prior to estimating annual and seasonal trends of aod over different aois in the region
finally, the aod and ae of the merra-2 dataset were used to classify the aerosol loading in the region into different classes
the results showed that the overall daily and monthly merra-2 and modis aods were in good spatial agreement with the ground-based aod
however, there was slight overestimation in the modis and underestimation in the merra-2 compared to aeronet aod
in contrast, the overall daily and monthly mmm aod not only indicated a good agreement higher than modis and merra-2 aod, but also showed an efficient estimation compared to aeronet aod

therefore, we recommended the authority of merra-2 to re-consider the merra-2 aod model by including the new version of modis c6.1 instead of c5.1. in general, modis, merra-2, and mmm were shown to be capable of fig

the trend analyses based on the merra-2 dataset from 1980 to 1997 and 1980 to 2018 showed that the regional annual aod during these periods had an insignificant and weak negative trend (ie 0.0009 and 0.0002 yr 1, respectively)

4. conclusions this study evaluated the accuracy of precipitation estimates produced by two satellite products: trmm (3b43v7) and gpm (imerg v6) in the sultanate of oman

for continuous statistics verification performance, indices such as correlation (r), rmse, and mae were used to compare the association between the satellite products and observed from 77 weather stations
study findings indicated that both gpm and trmm compared well with observed observations in 2016, when there was no tropical storm or cyclone
it is recommended that future studies investigate the performance of early runs of gpm for real-time extreme events such as cyclone monitoring in oman

in the current study, the following concluding remarks were drawn: there was generally a weak linear relationship between gpm and trmm in all the regions and years considered for the entire period of study, except for the good correlation observed in the northern region and also in 2016 (for the entire country)
from the change point analysis perspective, trmm and gpm compared well with observed in their ability to detect seasonal changes or aberrations in both annual and seasonal scales
in general, trmm and gpm showed similar characteristics with the observed in the number and timing of seasonal changes computed across the years
in all the years, there was strong agreement between trmm and gpm in terms of spatial distribution and magnitude
overall, this study assessed the performance of the gpm and trmm satellite products in oman
there were no marked di erences between the two products, suggesting that gpm can act as a reliable replacement for trmm

3.1. the moderate resolution imaging spectroradiometer (modis) instrument satellite observations have advantages over the ground-based management because they provide data on broad spatial domain
in this paper the last 19 years (2001-2019) record of aerosol optical depth at 0.55 m (aod) obtained from the modis instrument onboard the nasa eos terra satellite has been used
the atmospheric, oceanic and terrestrial data have been gathered using modis (moderate resolution imaging spectroradiometer) the sensor at 36 spectral bands
modis is a key instrument aboard the terra (eos am) and aqua (eos pm) satellites
terra satellite orbit around the fig
earth and it passes from north to south across the equator in the morning, while aqua passes south to north over the equator in the afternoon
the spectral bands of modis are very wide and range from visible to thermal infrared wavelengths
two kinds of long term and global-coverage aerosol products that are level 2 and level 3, which are derived from modis terra and aqua satellites

the level-2 daily (swath) product at 10-km (mxd04_l2, where o is for terra and y is for aqua) and 3-km (mxd04_3 k) resolutions, and level-3 daily (mxd08_d3), eight-day (mxd08_e3), and monthly (mxd08_m3) products at a 1◦ × 1◦ horizontal resolution
the satellite products from modis terra and aqua have beneficial to represent detailed local, regional and global distribution of several climatic parameters over land and the ocean
modis level 3 collection 6.1 deep blue (db), dark target (dt) and combined deep blue and dark target (cdb and dt) from 2000 onwards are available in terra satellite
according to jing et al (2019) terra and aqua aods show similar performance in capturing the aerosol trends
as a result of this, modis terra satellite has been used in order to analysis spatiotemporal distribution of aerosol optical depth over the lake tana basin
modis can be used to retrieve aod and ae and the correlation could be positive or negative
these trajectories are the part of gdas (gdas) dataset reprocessed by ncep (national centers for environmental prediction for the arl (air resources laboratory)
in order to understand the interaction of aerosols and clouds, modis satellite data are extracted
the spatial and temporal distribution of aod over the lake tana basin has been investigated using modis sensor terra satellite along with cloud microphysical properties

there are four major components in the modeling system: 1) nasa's goddard earth observing system model, version 5 (geos-5) that includes the production of nasa's merra, version 2 (merra-2); 2) casa and global fire emissions database (casa-gfed); 3) parameterized chemistry transport model (pctm); and 4) nu-wrf

supplement figure 1s shows the relationship of four components, in which geos-5/merra-2 provides meteorology to drive casa-gfed and pctm, as well as furnishes meteorological lateral boundary conditions (lbcs) to constrain nuwrf

since they had been well developed and evaluated, only brief introduction was given to each component in sections 2.1 through 2.4. the interface and modules newly developed to couple these four components were presented with details in sections 2.5 and 2.6. 2.1. geos-5/merra-2 geos-5 consists of an atmospheric general circulation model (agcm), a data assimilation system, a catchment-based land surface model, and an ocean model, all coupled together using the earth system modeling framework (esmf) (rienecker et al 2011; molod et al 2012; ott et al 2015)
the agcm utilizes the finite volume dynamic core developed by lin (2004) and the geos-5 column physics package (rienecker et al 2008)
geos-5 has been employed to produce the merra-2 (rienecker et al 2011; gelaro and coauthors, 2017), a reanalysis meteorological data product constrained by various observations
merra-2 bears a horizontal resolution of 0.5◦ (latitude) by 0.625◦ (longitude) with 72 vertical levels extending from surface to 0.01 hpa
for the present study, surface t, precipitation, and solar radiation from merra-2 were used to drive casa to compute terrestrial carbon fluxes

meteorological fields such as wind, t, and radiation out of merra-2, together with the carbon fluxes out of casa and other sources, were used to drive pctm to generate the temporospatial distributions of co2 mixing ratio over the globe
merra-2 meteorology was also utilized to provide the initial and boundary conditions to constrain nu-wrf

casa-gfed is driven by monthly meteorological data from merra-2 and a number of satellite derived products including modis vegetation classification and burned areas (giglio et al 2006, 2010), as well as the fraction of photosynthetically active radiation (fpar) out of the advanced very high-resolution radiometer (avhrr, los et al 2000; pinzon and tucker, 2014) at a 0.5◦ by 0.5◦ resolution

the generated monthly carbon fluxes are then disaggregated to 3-hourly values using merra-2's 3-h-averaged t at 2 m and surface downward solar radiation (olsen and randerson, 2004) together with daily satellite fire detections (mu et al 2011)

the forward simulation used in this study bore the same horizontal resolutions and vertical pressure level (56) grids as merra-2 (some of the most upper levels are merged to reduce computation with little impact on co2 mixing ratio)
the pctm outputs are used together with merra-2 meteorology as the initial and lateral boundary conditions to drive the regional model

the inputs to pctm include the 3-h-averaged winds, convective mass fluxes and scalar diffusivity from merra-2, the terrestrial 3-h-averaged co2 fluxes modulated from the casa-gfed monthly net primary production and heterotrophic respiration, the biomass burning co2 fluxes based on modis and casa-gfed, the monthly fossil fuel co2 fluxes from the co2 information analysis center (cdiac) at 1 ◦ × 1 ◦ resolution (andres et al 2016), and oceanic co2 fluxes from takahashi et al (2009)
merra2wrf module is a monolithic program customized to process the 6-hourly reanalysis data from merra-2 (peters-lidard et al 2015)
it extracts various 2-dimensional and 3-dimensional meteorological ifelds from 5 merra-2 output files, including air/skin t, pressure, geopotential, humidity, and wind
this way, the merra-2 meteorology is interpolated into nu-wrf initial and lateral boundary conditions
the chemistry driver, emissions driver, and initial/input data driver are all updated to take and process co2 data from various files processed by modules casa2wrf and merra2wrf

the physics package for the simulation was the same as the one used in the computational performance experiment described in section 2.6. the meteorological initial and boundary conditions were derived from merra-2 using the merra2wrf module
in addition, the total column co2 (xco2) measurements from the gosat (gosat) were used for model evaluation

the atmospheric co2 observations from space (acos) gosat/tanso-fts level 2 bias-corrected xco2 v7.3 (oco-2, 2016) was used in comparison to nu-wrf-casa xco2. the modeled, either based on pctm or nu-wrf-casa, co2 concentrations at each in situ tower location (3-dimensional, based on their latitudes, longitudes, and intake heights listed in table 1) and sampling time were extracted and compared to the respective observations

sediment traps were deployed at two mooring sites on the northern and southern flanks of the rise, north chatham rise (ncr) and south chatham rise (scr), respectively, from 1996 to 1997. the moorings are ~200 km apart, and subject to distinct hydrographic, but similar climatic conditions (sikes et al 2005)

the sites were chosen intitally to represent sites affected predominantly by processes within subtropical and subantarctic surface waters, respectively; however, it has more recently been established that the ncr and scr mooring sites are both within the outer fringes of the stfz (sutton 2001)

abbreviations: east cape current, ecc; wairarapa eddy, we; southland current, sc; north subtropical front, nstf; south subtropical front, stm; subtropical mooring, sam; subantarctic mooring, sstf; subtropical frontal zone, stfz (gray region); sediment trap mooring sites: north chatham rise, ncr; south chatham rise, scr; subtropical mooring, stm and subantarctic mooring, sam (indicated as orange dots; nodder et al 2016)

scr is affected by the flows associated with the strongest t gradients in the sstf on the southern flank of the chatham rise (chiswell 2001), explaining the higher, but less variable current speeds observed at scr than ncr (chiswell 2001; nodder and northcote 2001)

nutrient data from the csiro atlas of regional seas (dunn and ridgway 2002; ridgway et al 2002) indicates higher year-round silicate concentrations at ncr than scr, and higher concentrations of nitrate and phosphate at scr than ncr (sikes et al 2005)

mixed layer depths determined using the potential density difference from argo floats (deployed 2001-2006) indicate generally deeper and more seasonally variable mixed layers at ncr than scr (dong et al 2008)
at scr, the maximum mixed layer depth was 117 m in winter, while the minimum was 20 m (dong et al 2008)
moorings at the ncr and scr sites were each equipped with two mclane parflux mk 7g-21 sediment traps placed at 300 m and 1000 m depths, in a water depth of 1500 m
the scr bottles were poisoned with borax-buffered formalin (6%) to allow comparisons with other regional sediment trap lfux data-sets (nodder and alexander 1998)

the ncr traps were deployed at 42◦42s 178◦38e in early september 1996 while the scr traps were deployed at 44◦37s 178◦37e in late may 1996. both moorings were recovered in may 1997, theoretically sampling for 243 and 340 days, respectively

from midseptember 1996 until mid-december 1996 the sampling interval at ncr was 7-8 days, with twice as many sampling intervals in this period at ncr than scr, in order to obtain higher resolution sampling through the productive spring period

sampling intervals for the scr deployment were 16 days during the entire sampling period, with one missing sample in late march-early april at scr 300 m, reducing the total number of actual sample days to 324 days

in the stfz such particle sinking rates have been estimated to be ~100 m d 1 (nodder and northcote 2001), so sinking diatoms, especially in marine aggregates, may only take ~3 days to sink from the surface ocean to 300 m, the depth of the shallowest trap at ncr and scr

grazing was not measured in the present study, but zeldis et al (2002) estimated fecal pellet export at half to one third of scr 300 m poc export, and therefore potentially highly significant in comparison to phytoplankton fluxes

alkenone flux records from scr and ncr indicate high winter zooplankton grazing at both sites, but with zooplankton-related biomarker products dominating export production at ncr (sikes et al 2005), therefore indicating that in 1996-97, it is likely that grazing pressure was more pronounced at ncr

on the crest of the chatham rise, near-bed currents are certainly capable of remobilising the fine grain-size fraction of the seabed sediments (heath 1983; chiswell 1994) and current meter data associated with the ncr and scr moorings suggest that currents can reach maximum average speeds of 20-50 cm s 1 at 300 m, diminishing to 10-25 cm s 1 at 1000 m on the lfanks of the rise (nodder and northcote 2001)

currents were typically lower at scr, compared to ncr, but exhibited a pronounced west-to-east directionality that persisted for almost the entire year of the mooring deployment at scr, whereas currents were more variable in direction at ncr (nodder and northcote 2001)

8. the main findings of the present study are: higher phytoplankton (diatom and coccolith) fluxes at scr than at ncr likely reflects the proximity of the former to the strong frontal gradients associated with the southern extent of the subtropical frontal zone
conversely, diatom fluxes at scr were characterised by a predominance of cooler water taxa, supporting the contention that this site was more influ enced by subantarctic water mass processes
occasional input of subantarctic diatoms at ncr and subtropical species at scr was also evident, reflecting cross- and along-rise advection within the stfz (fig

8. schematic diagram (not to scale), summarising the inferred marine particle sources and pathways as suggested by the diatom, coccolith and downward particle fluxes captured by the ncr and scr sediment traps on the chatham rise within the stfz
in austral spring at scr accounted for ~98% of the annual diatom flux, and was associated with co-occurring high biogenic silica and poc downward fluxes

unlike the classical successional progression expected within phytoplankton communities (eg margalef, 1978), the seasonal progression, as inferred from the fluxes measured by sediment traps at scr and ncr, suggested that coccolithophores preceded diatoms during spring within the stfz

although it is still difficult to conclusively identify particle sources at ncr or scr, the stfz region may benefit from a future dedicated study investigating marine particle sources and transportation pathways, as such information will improve the veracity of export parameterisations in regional models, such as in the recently developed 'new zealand earth system model' (behrens et al 2020)
trmm 3b42v7 this study uses the trmm 3b42v7 product (huffman et al 2007)

it is based on version 7 of tmpa that combines multiple independent satellite precipitation estimates and uses calibrated infrared (ir) estimates to fill the passive microwave coverage gaps in time and space (huffman and bolvin 2018b)
tmpa has a 3-h temporal resolution and a 0.258 spatial resolution, and it is corrected by the monthly gauge data
previous studies have reported that tmpa is generally more accurate over the ocean than over land (ebert et al 2007; sapiano and arkin 2009) because the algorithm uses both low- and fig
1. spatial distribution of rain gauges in the contiguous united states (orange) and mexico (blue)
the time period that we focused on in this study is from 2014 to 2018, which is the transitional period from trmm to gpm

although the trmm satellite descended to an altitude that precluded useful pr data in october 2014 and it was completely shut down in april 2015, the tmpa product continued to be generated till december 2019. as noted in huffman (2020), nasa kept generating tmpa using other data sources until the gpm products can supersede it completely
huffman (2020) also stated that ''the actual demise of trmm is not the substantive issue for the tmpa

'' therefore, we believe that during the transitional period (2014-18), when trmm had been shut down and gpm had not yet fully calibrated and understood, tmpa provides high-quality data generated using a consistent algorithm
the gpm era started in 2014 with the launch of the gpm core observatory
the transitional period (2014-18) provides coverage from both tmpa and imerg and it is the best option for evaluating the improvement of imerg over tmpa
this is also why most previous comparisons of tmpa and imerg were performed using this time period
gpm imerg v06 in this study, we used the recently released gpm imerg v06 data (final run, hereafter referred to as imerg-f), which has a 0.18 spatial resolution and a 30-min temporal resolution

imerg-f merges, interpolates, and cross calibrates different satellite-derived precipitation estimates, including microwave precipitation estimates, microwave-calibrated infrared (ir) satellite estimates and precipitation gauge analyses
imerg-f is also corrected by monthly gauge data
match the spatial resolution of tmpa
the original imerg-f data (0.18) is also included in spatial-average analyses
the imerg-f product has a half-hour temporal resolution and a 0.18 spatial resolution

tmpa calibrates the tmi (before 2015), advanced microwave scanning radiometer for earth observing systems (amsr-e), special sensor microwave imager (ssmi), ssmis (ssmis), advanced msu (amsu), and mhs (mhs) to the tci

although tmpa has been one of the most widely used satellite precipitation products, our evaluation shows that tmpa underestimates tcp in the locations that receive more rainfall and overestimates tcp in the locations that receive less rainfall from tc events
aghakouchak et al (2011) found that tmpa products tend to miss a significant volume of extreme rainfall in the united states
chen et al (2013a) compared the tmpa-based tcp with the comprehensive pacific rainfall database in australia and found that tmpa performs poorly at coastal and island sites with higher elevations
our results show that imerg-f performed better than tmpa at capturing tcp both for times and locations that received extremely heavy rainfall and for those that received lower amounts of rainfall
one of the reasons that imerg-f outperforms tmpa may be due to the improved morphing scheme

replaced the ir precipitation scheme used to fill in the gaps in microwave precipitation in tmpa with the cmorph (joyce et al 2004) and persiann (hong et al 2004) schemes

this improvement not only provides a finer time resolution so that system evolution is more accurately captured, compared to the 3-h interval in tmpa, but also minimizes the low-quality ir contribution, which is only kept for filling long microwave gaps
spatial resolution is another fundamental improvement of imerg over tmpa

previous studies have demonstrated that the coarse spatial resolution of tmpa (0.258) causes heavy precipitation to be underestimated over land (tang et al 2016) because heavy rainfall usually occurs at finer spatial and temporal scales (fang et al 2019; touma et al 2018)
imerg improved the spatial resolution to 0.18. this leads to an improved ability to capture the spatial heterogeneity of heavy precipitation
to demonstrate this, we show the spatial pattern of tcp in hurricane harvey based on the original imerg-f data (0.18 spatial resolution) in fig
12a and compare it with the gauge observations, tmpa and regridded imerg-f in figs
the spatial heterogeneity of tcp is better captured by the original 0.18 imerg-f data
the maximum tcp captured by the original imerg-f data (798 mm) is larger than those based on tmpa and regridded imerg-f (,750 mm), which is closer to the gauge observations
the original imerg-f data also performs better than tmpa and regridded imerg-f in terms of capturing light rainbands
the light rainband over the junction of louisiana, arkansas, and mississippi, which is missed by both tmpa and regridded imerg-f, is well captured by the original imerg-f
the ks statistic between the cdf of the original imerg-f and the gauge observation is significantly (p , 0.05) smaller than that of tmpa and regridded imerg-f

11. spatial pattern of tcp errors (mm) in hurricane harvey (2017): (a) tmpa-gauge observations and (b) imerg-gauge observations, and hurricane florence (2018) (d) tmpa-gauge observations and (e) imerg-gauge observations
other theoretical reasons, such as extended microwave channels (up to 183 ghz) and more accurate reference data, may also improve the performance of imerg on capturing tcp
in this study, we assumed that gauge observations are the ground truth and we used them to evaluate tmpa and imerg-f-based tcp
another challenge for evaluating satellite estimation using observations from rain gauges is timing mismatch
for example, tmpa's 3-h temporal interval can cause at most 1.5-h offset from the time of gauge observation
in addition, our rain-gaugeestimated daily tcp is partially independent of tmpa and imerg-f since they both use monthly gpcc gauge-based product for corrections
our analysis offers insights into the differences between rain gauges and satellite observations at the daily scale, with a focus on tcs

moreover, since both tmpa and imerg-f are corrected with reference to monthly climatology, which is usually lower than actual tcp, the undercatch correction can lead to the underestimation of satellite products on capturing tcp

12. (a) spatial pattern of tcp (mm) in hurricane harvey (2017) based on imerg at its original grid cell (0.18 spatial resolution) and (b) cumulative distribution functions of gauge observation (blue), tmpa (red), regridded imerg (yellow), and original imerg (purple)
last but not least, since imerg has only incorporated gpm observations since 2014, our study is limited to 5 years
as more data become available, this evaluation can be extended to provide more information about long-term trends and variability and to improve our understanding of the performance of imerg
this study provides a comprehensive evaluation of the accuracy of tmpa and imerg-f during tc events

both products were evaluated by comparing with gauge observations over the united states and mexico from 2014 to 2018. imerg-f incorporates more advanced sensors and uses improved algorithms to estimate precipitation

this study has two novel aspects: 1) evaluating tmpa- and imerg-f-based tropical cyclone precipitation, and 2) using gauge-based reference data that have undergone wind loss adjustment and special processing to better represent true tcp
the main findings are as follows: 1) both tmpa and imerg-f were generally able to accurately capture mean annual tcp over the united states and mexico
tmpa slightly underestimates mean annual tcp, while imerg-f shows no significant differences with gauge observations
spatially, both tmpa and imerg-f can accurately reproduce variations in mean annual tcp
however, both tmpa and imerg-f significantly underestimated precipitation in the regions that receive the most tcp

even so, the performance of imerg-f was significantly better than tmpa in these regions because it had a higher correlation coefficient and fewer locations with statistically significant differences with the gauge observations than tmpa
there is no significant difference between the original and the interpolated imerg-f at annual scale
2) focusing on the event-based analysis of tcp, imerg-f improved the performance significantly in 17, 14, and 27 (out of 31) tc events over tmpa based on mae, re, and nse, respectively
the original imerg-f shows the highest correlation with gauge observation at event scale, followed by the interpolated imerg-f and tmpa

3) the case study analysis of the two extreme tcp events, hurricane harvey (2017) and hurricane florence (2018), revealed that both imerg-f and tmpa systematically underestimate the maximum tcp by ;150 mm
however, imerg-f outperforms tmpa in most locations
4) at the daily time scale, the underestimations by imergf and tmpa increase substantially when the tcp
the differences between imerg-f and the gauges are consistently smaller than those between tmpa and the gauges
in conclusion, we have demonstrated that imerg-f provides more accurate estimates of tcp as compared to tmpa on all time scales

however, neither imerg-f nor tmpa is able to accurately estimate heavy tcp
