six (6) years (2008-2013) precipitation data obtained by the precipitation radar (pr) of the tropical rain measuring mission (trmm) satellite and reprocessed using the gpm (gpm) algorithm are used for the study
the trmm satellite is a research tool launched in 1997 by the united states' national aeronautical and space administration (nasa) in conjunction with the japan aerospace exploration agency (jaxa)

by covering tropical, sub-tropical, and temperate regions of the earth, trmm provides the needed information on rainfall and other related parameters that assist researchers at the global platform to account for atmospheric circulation with enhanced ability to carry out a forecast (rotimi et al 2017)
the pr is capable of providing the needed rainfall profile and other related information covering the tropical and sub-tropical regions of the world
the trmm-pr is the first space-borne rain radar and the only instrument on trmm that can directly observe vertical distributions of rain
the frequency of trmm pr is 13.8 ghz
the precipitation radar (pr) measures rain parameters in 5◦ by 5◦ grid resolution as required by the trmm mission
the pr can achieve quantitative measurement of rain parameters such as freezing height, brand band height, amount of precipitation over land as well as the ocean

the footprint size of pr is small enough to allow for the study of inhomogeneous rainfall effects upon the comparatively coarse footprints of the low-frequency microwave radiometer channels (jaxa, 2011)
the trmm-pr data product used for this work is the pr 2a23 version 7. the algorithm for extraction and processing 2a23 v7 is contained in the product manual (jaxa, 2011)

rain flag, rain type, bright band height (bbh), bright band status, intensity, freezing height levels (fhl) also known as zero degree isotherm heights (zdih) h0, and other rain-related parameters were extracted from trmm-pr
based on the 13.8 ghz frequency band for the operation of trmm pr, it is fairly heavily attenuated during rainfall

thus, the algorithm uses attenuation-corrected radar echo intensities retrieved from tmm-pr to generate the rainfall rate needed for estimation of rain heights (trmm manual, 1999 and iguchi et al 2000)
the following instructions were used to extract bbh and zdih from stratiform and convective rain types retrieved from pr

when there are missing fhl data, it is flagged 9999. when there is an error in the estimation of the fhl, the algorithm error symbol is 5555. it is worth mentioning that the data used for this research is the gpm (gpm) data sets
this is the reprocessed and an improved version of trmm-pr data obtained using the new gpm algorithm

the gpm data has several advantages over the trmm data such as better file naming convention, improvement on rain rate integration time, merging of level 2 and 3 datasets thus reduction in ifle sizes, migration from hdf4 to hdf5 format, the extended capability to measure light rain (<0.5 mm/h), solid precipitation and the microphysical properties of precipitating particles (nasa, 2018)
equation (1) was used to compute the rain heights where ho is the zdih extracted from gpm and hs is the mean height of the ground station above the sea level

in this work, six (6) years precipitation data retrieved from the gpm (gpm) constellation satellites have been used to compute zdih, rain height at a location in the sub-sahel and coastal regions in nigeria
the nasa gpm and ecmwf data are available at ://=sfc/respectively
the insitu observations include automatic weather stations (aws), meteorological aviation report (metar) observations, and micrometeorological tower observations
the merra (merra; rienecker et al 2011) hourly analysis at 0.5 9 0.66 is used as background to carry out objective analysis for the surface meteorological parameters

hourly surface meteorological parameters including air t (t2) and specific humidity at 2-m height (q2), surface pressure (psfc), and zonal (u10) and meridional (v10) winds at 10-m height from merra are used as background

similarly, gridded (0.1 9 0.1 ) rainfall at 3-h is generated considering the trmm (trmm; huffman et al 2007) 3b42 3-h precipitation as background, and insitu rainfall observations are used to update the background

the ldas uses an uncoupled 2d noah-lsm (chen et al 1996; chen and dudhia 2001) that integrates near-surface atmospheric parameters, static surface fields (land use and soil type), and monthly vegetation characteristics, and estimates land surface conditions such as sm and st at four soil layers (0-10 cm; 10-40 cm; 40-100 cm; and 100-200 cm) and surface fluxes
the overestimation of sm during intense rainfall spells (peak sm values) is primarily attributed the higher soil porosity and field capacity used in the noah-lsm (lsm; nayak et al 2019)

hourly surface forcing parameters such as t2, q2, u10, v10, and psfc at 0.1 9 0.1 horizontal resolution are prepared for the period 2009-2013 by using merra as background, and insitu observations are used to update the background fields
similarly, the gridded 3-h rainfall input (0.1 9 0.1 ) are prepared using trmm data as background

2.1. oco-2 data oco-2 is an atmospheric co2 observing satellite launched by national aeronautics and space administration (nasa) in 2014, flying in a 705 km sun-synchronous near-polar orbit with equator crossing time near 13:36 (local time) and a 16-day ground track repeat cycle (osterman et al 2018)
oco-2 makes observations by using 8 adjacent soundings across a swath no wide than 10 km
oco-2 is routinely making around 1 million observations each day, and more than 10% of these observations are sufficiently cloud-free to retrieve xco2 precisely (osterman et al 2018)
the xco2 retrieved from oco-2 observations have a median difference of less than 0.5 ppm and root mean square differences typically below 1.5 ppm compared with tccon (wunch et al 2017)

in this study, by adding an observation operator module and a xco2 retrievals aggregation module, and by modifying existing modules, the dart was extended to be able to assimilate the oco-2 xco2 retrievals

the xco2 retrievals from nadir observation mode with good quality according to the xco2_quality_flag were selected from the latest version of oco-2 level 2 (l2) lite data product v9r (oco-2 science team/michael gunson and eldering, 2018)

among them, xb is the prior vertical profile, aco2 is the column averaging kernel, j corresponds to the layer ordinal of the oco-2 pressure levels, h is the pressure weighting function, xcob2 is the prior of oco-2 xco2 retrieval

2.2. kldas kldas was established using the noah-lsm with multi-parameterization, version 3.6 (noah-mp; cai et al 2014) at a 0.01 spatial resolution grid with a 15-min timestep to generate daily energy and water balance variables

in this study, we used the modified international geosphere biosphere programme 20-category landuse data from the moderate resolution imaging spectroradiometer (modis; friedl et al 2002), monthly climatologies of leaf area index (lai) and greenness fraction from the noaa avhrr (avhrr; gutman et al 1998)
the merra, version 2 (merra-2; reichle et al 2017) datasets were used to force the model
merra-2 is available globally at the hourly time step and horizontal resolution of 2/3 longitude by 1/2 latitude
the combined asos and gts precipitation dataset replaced the merra-2 precipitation fields

other meteorological inputs (ie air t, humidity, pressure, winds, radiation) from merra-2 were adjusted for the elevation differences through lapse-rate and slope-aspect correction methods (kumar et al 2013) and downscaled to 0.01 gridded data

in contrast to the same lsm used in the two versions, gldas-2.0 was entirely forced with the princeton meteorological forcing data on a 1 gridded data (sheffield et al 2006) whereas gldas-2.1 was forced with a combination of national center for environmental prediction's gdas (gdas) atmospheric analysis fields on a 0.2 gridded data (derber et al 1991) and global precipitation climatology project (gpcp) precipitation field on a 1 gridded data (adler et al 2003)
the simulation was forced by a combination of the merra-2 data and climate hazards group infrared precipitation with station (chirps; funk et al 2015) 6-hourly rainfall data

note that compared to spatial resolution differences amongst the three ldas products, the fao's global soil texture maps (used in gldas) and the merra-2 meteorological forcing dataset (used in kldas) were rescaling into 0.10 gridded data to inputs to the fldas

the global product combined satellite soil moisture retrievals from four passive (ie the nimbus 7 scanning multi-channel microwave radiometer (smmr), the special sensor microwave imagers (ssm/i) of the dmsp, the tmi (tmi), and the advanced microwave scanning radiometer-earth observing system (amsr-e) sensor on nasa's aqua satellite) and two active (the european remote sensing satellites 1 and 2 active microwave instrument (ami) wind scatterometer and the advanced scatterometer (ascat) onboard the meteorological operational platform)

merra-2 is a nasa atmospheric reanalysis for the satellite era using the goddard earth observing system model, version 5 (geos-5) with its atmospheric data assimilation system (adas), version 5.12.4. the merra project provides the global-scale, time averaged, and pressurelevel specific wind profiles with a spatial resolution 0.5 ◦ × 0.625 ◦

in this work, the monthly averaged merra-2 wind profile data products (zonal and meridional components of winds) were obtained from nasa goddard earth sciences data and information services center (ges disc) operated by global modeling and assimilation office (gmao)
to perform computations, the aerosol profile from calipso and wind components from merra-2 were normalized to match with each other

among the available satellite products for aod, data from the seviri (seviri) (emili et al 2010), multiangle imaging spectroradiometer (misr) (sotoudeheian & arhami, 2014), modis (feng et al 2019; krishna et al 2019a, b), medium resolution imaging spectrometer and advanced along-track scanning radiometer (meris/aatsr) (beloconi et al 2016; kanniah et al 2014) and landsat 8 oli (saraswat et al 2017) are commonly used to estimate ground level pm10 and/or pm2.5. modis is a key instrument in earth observing system's terra (mod) and aqua (myd) satellites launched in 1999 and 2002, respectively (riggs et al 2017) and observes the earth from 700-km altitude with a swath of 2330 km
the modis covers nearly the entire earth every 1-2 days, with a 16-day repeat cycle and acquires data in 36 spectral bands

the orbital timing of the tera around the earth is tuned in such a way that it passes from north to south direction (descending node) and crosses the equator in the morning, while as the aqua passes in reverse direction (south to north, ascending node) and crosses the equator in the afternoon (mhawish et al 2018)
specifically, modis passes over the kashmir himalaya twice daily, terra between 10:30 h and 12:00 h local time (lt), and aqua between 13:00 and 14:30 h lt

three operational algorithms are employed for the retrieval of aerosols properties over land and ocean surfaces from modis: deep blue (db) algorithm over land, dark target (dt) algorithm over land and dt algorithm over ocean (a
the db and dt algorithms for c6.0 and c6.1 contain standard 10-km spatial resolution for the terra (mod04_l2) and aqua (myd04_l2) retrievals

for more precise local and regional aerosol features and loading, a 3-km spatial resolution dataset was also included in product for both the terra (mod03_3k) and aqua (myd_3k) platforms (remer et al 2013)

recent studies suggest that modis 3-km data product is not yet fully evaluated at regional scale and showed week agreement with the ground measurements compared to the standard modis 10-km data product (he et al 2017; nichol & bilal, 2016)
therefore, modis daily l2, c6.1 merged aod_550_dark_target_deep_blue combined product from both terra (mod04_l2) and aqua (myd04_l2) was used in this study for the retrieval of aod
on most of the observation days, aod was available either from the terra or aqua over the observation site due to the persistent cloud cover and high snow albedo

therefore, average aod of the two observations was used in the analysis so as to compensate for the diurnal variability in aod captured by the aqua and terra at two different time intervals (ferrero et al 2019), and thus representing the daily aod more efficiently

2.1. oco-3 xco2 data the oco-3 instrument is currently mounted to the japanese experimental module - exposed facility (jem-ef) on board of the iss and collects solar radiance spectra over the sunlit hemisphere in four observational modes: nadir, glint, target, and sam
during target mode observations, oco-3 collects a series of relatively long segments (usually 5 or 6 segments) resulting in a sequence of overlapping along-track swaths

similar to oco-2, oco-3's target mode observations provide the primary dataset for validation of the xco2 product and are typically taken over sites that operate ground based tccon instruments (wunch et al 2011a, 2017)
the overlapping swaths can cover an area of up to 20 × 80 km2 (compared to 20 × 20 km2 for oco-2), also creating small maps of xco2 over tccon city sites

oco-3 has also a slightly larger footprint size compared to oco-2. the oco-3 along track footprint size is 2.2 km at nadir and the cross-track footprint size is 1.6 km, resulting in a slightly larger footprint area (3.5 km2) compared to oco-2 (3 km2)

in this study, we focus on the first xco2 sam and target mode observations taken by the oco-3 instrument over la in october 2019 and february 2020. we use the oco-3 vearly product which is publicly available through the nasa goddard earth science data and information services center (ges disc) for distribution and archiving ()

as described in taylor et al (2020), the oco-3 vearly data contains time dependent residual pointing errors that occasionally exceed oco-3's footprint size, especially for large azimuth and elevation positions of the pma
for our analysis, we carefully checked the oco-3 target and sam mode data for possible pointing errors by investigating radiance levels of oco3's o2 a-band data from coastline crossing
the pointing error in the data analyzed here appears to be below oco-3's footprint size and the data is well suited for investigations of city scale xco2 gradients
a detailed description of the oco-3 vearly xco2 data product and its data quality is given in (taylor et al 2020; osterman et al 2020)
the tccon is a global network of high-resolution ground-based ace-ftss that record solar spectra in the nearinfrared region
tccon is the primary validation source for the oco-3 xco2 data product and has m
kiel et al been used to validate data from multiple satellites, eg oco-2, gosat, tropomi, and mopitt (wunch et al 2011b; o'dell et al 2018; borsdorff et al 2018; kiel et al 2019; hedelius et al 2019)
we use the caltech tccon data to validate oco-3 xco2 measurements over the northern part of la and the tccon afrc xco2 dataset to derive background xco2 estimates for each oco-3 overpass
the innermost domain (1.3 km spatial resolution in latitude and longitude) fully covers the oco-3 sam and target mode observations over la
finally, we apply oco-3's pressure weighting functions (pwf) and averaging kernels (ak) to the model data following rodgers and connor (2003)
the tropomi (tropomi) on board of the copernicus sentinel-5p (s5p) satellite was launched in 2017 and measures tropospheric column densities of several key atmospheric species
a single tropomi overpass can be sufficient to identify strong no2 point sources
reuter et al (2019) showed that tropomi no2 measurements can help to identify urban co2 plumes
to better characterize the spatiotemporal variability of xco2 over la, we relate xco2 from oco3 to co-emitted no2 concentration as observed by tropomi
we found co-located no2 data within 3 h of the oco-3 overpasses on three days that we include in our analysis

here, we relate xco2 from oco-3 measurements to co-emitted no2 concentration as observed by tropomi to verify that the observed xco2 distributions represent a true signal that is driven by local emissions
the tropomi instrument collected data over la within three hours of the oco-3 overpass on three days analyzed here
on october 7, 2019 the tropomi overpass was 1 h after the oco-3 overpass, and on october 11, 2019, 3 h after the oco-3 overpass

there is no co-located data within five hours of the oco-3 overpass on october 15, 2019. a direct comparison between data from both instruments is challenging due to the short lifetime of no2 and the temporal mismatch (in addition to instrumental differences and sensitivities), however, the spatial distribution of tropomi's no2 over la is similar to the spatial distribution of xco2 measured by oco-3: higher no2 concentrations over the suburbs to the northeast on october 7, 2019; low no2 concentrations over large parts of the city on october 11, 2019; and enhanced no2 concentration over the urban core on february 24, 2020 (see fig
tropomi's wide-swath no2 measurements help to set the xco2 city enhancements into context

tropomi no2 measurements are taken in the uv-visible spectral region (425-465 nm) and are less sensitive to clouds and aerosols compared to oco-3. the observed spatial correlation between both datasets suggests that the observed xco2 enhancements over la are dominated by local xco2 emissions and are less likely due to remaining artifacts in the oco-3 vearly xco2 data product
on three days, the oco-3 target and sam observations capture xco2 values that are comparable to background xco2 values measured at the afrc tccon site
this demonstrates that oco-3's multi-swath measurement approach reasonably captures city enhancements and background values at the same time on a single overpass
moreover, oco-3 measurements reveal fine-scale, intra-urban xco2 variations over la with unprecedented spatial coverage
further, the observed intra-urban xco2 variations are in good agreement with co-located tropomi no2 data

oco-3's high-resolution subcity observations provide insights into the variability of urban co2 contributions and can pave the way towards localized emission reduction strategies
the uncertainty spread is larger for oco-3 than for both models and, in general, largest when xco2 enhancements are large as well

analyzing x-stilt's source-receptor sensitivities, the sensitivity of downwind co2 variations to upwind fluxes, show that oco-3's sam observations capture about three times as much of the city emissions compared to single-swath overpasses
future studies using oco-3 target and sam observations will help to constrain city emissions on sub-city scales and offer insights to examine potential errors and biases in emission inventories

oco-3's multi-swath measurement approach allows collection of dense maps of xco2 over emission hot spots and is potentially able to capture intra-urban xco2 variations from space with unprecedented spatial resolution

on three days, the oco-3 target and sam observations were not only able to reveal unique intra-urban xco2 distributions over la, but also captured xco2 values that agree with background concentration measured by the afrc tccon instrument
this demonstrates that oco-3's multi-swath measurement approach is able to capture city enhancements and background values at the same time on only one single overpass
analyzing x-stilt's source-receptor sensitivities, we found that oco-3's sam observations capture about three times as much of the city emissions compared to single-swath overpasses
oco-3's sam and target mode measurements provide an innovative dataset for carbon studies on sub-city scale
the emission coverage by oco-3 will help to constrain urban emissions at finer spatiotemporal scales, especially in regions with limited ground-based monitoring capabilities

this work shows that future wide-swath co2 missions with oco-3 type dense sampling and short revisit times, for example geocarb (moore iii et al 2018), aimnorth (nassar et al 2019), or co2m (sierk et al 2019), can play a major role in quantifying enhancements over urban areas, potentially monitoring the effectiveness and progress of localized co2 emission reduction policies

this study used the daily nadir bidirectional reflectance distribution function (brdf) adjusted reflectance product from moderateresolution imaging spectroradiometer (mcd43a4 v006, 500 m) and 8day composite modis surface reflectance product (mod09a1 v006, 500 m) to derive the evi and ndvi data
the mcd43a4 data set is produced using daily terra and aqua satellite overpasses within each 16day window by the brdf to model the reflectance at local solar noon
the mod09a1 data set was obtained by modis onboard the terra satellite and the equatorial overpass is at about 10:30 local solar time
daily vod data at a 0.1 spatial resolution were derived from passive microwave remote sensing data from the amsr2 (amsr2), using the land parameter retrieval model (lprm) (owe et al 2008)
amsr2 scans the earth's surface in an ascending (day time) and descending (night time) mode
the 500m modis data set were gridded in 0.05 × 0.05 windows in accordance with the geographic locations of study sites
the 0.05 grids were excluded if over 20% of the 500 m pixels within the grid were identified as lowquality observations by the qa flag for the modis data set
amsr2 vod product was obtained from the ges disc ()

following many previous west african studies (toledo machado et al 1992; arnaud et al 1992; laing et al 1999; mathon et al 2002), we identify individual mcss using thermal-infrared imagery on board the meteosat series of geostationary satellites

meteosat satellites (first and second generation) provide subhourly records of cloud-top ts, covering a climatological time period going back to 1982. they provide a full image of the african continent at least every 30 min at a spatial resolution of ;3-5 km

gridsat-b1 is cross-calibrated and corrected for effects of sensor changes between different meteosat satellites with the aim to create a homogenized dataset that is suitable for climate variability and trend analyses, with an estimated calibration uncertainty of less than 0.18c per decade (knapp et al 2011)

therefore, era5 trend patterns in moisture-related variables were compared to trends in the merra-2 reanalysis over the same time period (0.58, gelaro et al 2017), and are briefly discussed but not shown in the results
for this we use the original meteosat second generation (msg) cloud-top t data, which are available every 15 min from the eumetsat archive (schmetz et al 2002; https://navigator
rainfall snapshots are taken from the ''high-quality precipitation'' (hq) field within the imerg (imerg; huffman et al 2019) dataset
this variable is based solely on passive microwave estimates, which better preserves spatial rainfall structures than the full imerg product

we note that gpm-imerg rainfall over africa has been found to be of a comparable quality to its predecessor trmm3b42, showing a reasonable accordance with rain gauge data in southern west africa (dezfuli et al 2017)
in a detailed validation study against rain gauges in southern ghana, (maranan et al 2020) identified a systematic underestimation of subdaily high-intensity rainfall
they found this underestimation to be aggravated by the gauge calibration for the final imerg product, which additionally motivates our use of the passive microwave-only product for this mcs study

positive trends in low-level moisture are also found in the merra-2 reanalysis, but located 500 km farther south, where era5 shows no trend, while tcwv trend magnitude and pattern correspond well (not shown), illustrating the uncertainty in inferring moisture trends from reanalyses
this is in line with maranan et al (2018), who inferred from trmm rainfall radar data that the majority of rainbearing systems with deep and wide convective cores occurs in mam

the exceedance probability of the determined rainfall threshold (xth = 430 mm) was calculated as p = 0.0265. from this, the probability of experiencing at least one extreme event, greater than the threshold, over n years, pr(n), can be calculated as follows: prn tn11pt1p 11pn : the concept of the pr(n) is referred to as risk of failure defined by yen (1970)
then, the concept of the pr(n) was employed to calculate the temporal probability of landslide occurrences

if there is no representative rainfall station, or the rainfall record is too short to conduct the extreme value analysis, satellite-based rainfall data, such as trmm, can be used to estimate the temporal probability of landslide occurrences
in fact, gauged data and trmm data produced differences in the temporal probabilities of rainfall-induced landslide occurrences of less than 3% for all the analysis period
therefore, when the gauge-based rainfall data are not available, trmm rainfall data can be a viable alternative

the moderate resolution imaging spectroradiometer (modis), onboard terra (launched in 1999) and aqua (launched in 2002), is a scanning radiometer that provides terrestrial, atmospheric, and oceanic observations (king et al 1992)
additionally, modis provides thermal anomaly and fire detection products (giglio et al 2016)

the visible infrared imaging radiometer suite (viirs) is a scanning radiometer aboard the suomi-npp (snpp, launched in 2011) and noaa-20 (formerly joint polar satellite system (jpss)-1, launched in 2017)
viirs measures cloud and aerosol properties in the atmosphere and provides observations of land, cryosphere, and ocean surface (jackson et al 2013)
the map of viirs aod is taken from the noaa aerosolwatch website ()
the omps aerosol index (ai) product is determined by the difference in surface reflectivity derived from 340 to 378.5 nm backscatter radiances
we used the omps level-3 version 2.1 daily gridded (1◦ × 1◦) ai product and the data were obtained from nasa goddard earth sciences data and information services center (ges disc) ()
2.2.5. airs co the airs (airs) is a hyperspectral infrared spectroradiometer onboard the aqua satellite (launched in 2002)
with 2378 spectral channels, airs provides a daily global 3-dimensional view of atmospheric conditions and trace gases

the airs co (co) product was retrieved from the spectral radiances in the 4.50-4.58 m region and has been used as an indicator for smoke plumes (mcmillan et al 2005; vadrevu et al 2014; yurganov et al 2011)
we used the airs level-3 daily gridded (1◦ × 1◦) co product from nasa ges disc
we further integrate the airs co molecular concentrations from 850 to 500 hpa as the indicator of smoke plumes aloft

the merra-2 aerosol product consists of five aerosol species, including mineral dust, sea salt, so4, bc, and oc

based on those results, nasa's merra, version 2 (merra-2) reanalysis is selected here to provide the necessary atmospheric inputs to all clear-sky irradiance models under consideration

finally, to encourage truly comparable studies in the future, the codes of the aforementioned models are made freely available through github , at , the models and methods of downloading and extracting merra-2 reanalysis are fully detailed and freely available in the irradpy python package
in particular, what was then referred to as the pr model is now renamed psi-rest for clarity
as mentioned previously, the atmospheric inputs required by the clear-sky irradiance models are taken from the gridded reanalysis dataset merra-2
merra-2 provides high-quality global coverage on a grid of 0.5◦ × 0.625◦ with 1-h temporal resolution from 1980 to the preceding 2 months

whilst there is no nearly-perfect input dataset and alternative global datasets for obtaining irradiance data do exist , such as the copernicus atmosphere monitoring service (cams) from the european center for medium-range weather forecasts (ecmwf), earlier studies found that merra-2 had good balance between data availability and its spatio-temporal resolution and extent, and thus reduces the impact of data uncertainty onto solar irradiance estimations
nevertheless, a recent validation of the merra-2 aerosol data revealed that they could be affected by signifi cant bias and dispersion, depending on climate region or continent
hence, by using the merra-2 reanalysis data as inputs, one must accept that error propagation is likely to occur
this means that the performance assessment herein is strictly tied to the merra-2 input data, and that different results or model rankings could well be obtained with different input data
however, this does not detract from the impact of this research because merra-2 is widely used in many solar energy studies and can be easily accessed and customised using the irradpy python package

this is done via a scale-height approximation : (h) = (h0) e(h0 h)/ha , uh2o(h) = uh2o(h0) e(h0 h)/hv , where h is the elevation of the ground validation station, and h0 is the elevation above mean sea level of the corresponding merra-2 grid cell
this cell height is itself obtained by dividing the surface gph (merra-2's phis variable) by the average table 2 hourly atmospheric input data extracted from the merra-2 database

starting from the native merra-2 data at 1-h temporal resolution, interpolation using a piecewise cubic hermite interpolating polynomial (pchip)-an option in matlab's interp2 interpolation function-is employed to derive the required 1-min estimates
all models are operated at the center time of each 1-min measurement period, using the corresponding merra-2 inputs after they have been synchronised using the interpolation process explained earlier
additionally, the model predictions can be affected by the bias in the merra-2 aod data, which is not negligible in the polar climate class
an explanation is that its atmospheric inputs are not from merra-2, but from a different reanalysis database, namely the copernicus atmosphere monitoring service (cams)
this suggests that the ranking of models found here (based on merra-2 inputs, except for mcclear) is specific, and could be altered if a different database (eg cams) had been selected instead

those inputs have been extracted from the merra-2 hourly reanalysis, selected here for its high quality and global coverage

in this study, we examined the performances of three gridded precipitation data sets for the period 19852009, gpcc, trmm, and merra, by comparing them with the observed precipitation data of 9 rain gauge stations located across the sina basin, india

the following conclusions are made based on the results of this study: i the trmm data showed good performance in terms of pbias, nrmse, nse, and md at the majority of the stations, and in terms of ve, merra performed well at 8 stations
overall, the performance of trmm was found best at maximum number of rain gauge stations followed by merra and gpcc
j based on the cpi, trmm ranks the first position with the best performance at almost all the stations except kalgaon station
the trmm data set has demonstrated excellent efficiency compared to the gpcc and merra data sets

m the probability distribution of the observed data set at various frequencies matches well with the trmm and gpcc data sets at stations located in the southern part (ie alni, bandalgi, kasegaon, and solapur)
the ecdf trends at monthly and annual scales revealed that merra tends to underestimate the intensities and values of rain gauge data, whereas trmm and gpcc tend to overestimate them

although trmm overestimates the intensities and values of rain gauge data, it has higher correlation with the observed data and also recorded very close values to monthly mean values of observed data in the rainy season as compared to the other two data sets

n the analysis of precipitation data at the annual scale revealed that the trmm data set replicates the observed data characteristics very well especially at the stations located in the southern part of the study area, while the merra data set has somewhat good performance compared with trmm at chinchodi patil, supa, and kalgaon stations
the data analysis at extreme rainfall points also indicated the superior performance of trmm data set
overall, the trmm data set performs very well in the study area

therefore, the trmm data set is recommended as a suitable gridded precipitation data set for climatic and/or hydrological studies in the study area as well as in the areas having similar hydro-climatic conditions

2.1. long-term co and aod measured from space the nasa/terra satellite, launched in december 1999, carries two key instruments for the work of this paper, mopitt and modis
terra follows a sun-synchronous orbit with equator crossing times of ~10:30 local solar time (lst)

the recent version 8 (v8) algorithm includes: updates to the n2 and h2o spectroscopic data; accounting for temporal bias drift and h2o in the radiance bias correction; and updating to modis cloud collection version 6.1 to determine clear conditions
buchholz et al product in order to compare with other tir instruments (airs, tes, iasi, cris, introduced below)

level-2 total column co retrievals are used for regional trend analysis and monthly statistics (doi: 10.5067/terra/mopitt/mop02t_l2.008), while level-3 monthly averaged total column co is used for the global gridded trend and zonal average analyses (doi: 10.5067/terra/ mopitt/mop03tm_l3.008)
2.1.2. modis aod as a passive imaging radiometer, modis measures reflected solar and thermal radiation in 36 bands with a 2330 km wide viewing swath, achieving near global coverage each day
modis collection 6.1 (c6.1) represents a consistent reprocessing of all modis products, including original geolocation, calibration, aerosol retrieval, and level 3 aggregation
in this work, we have used the c6.1 monthly aggregations from modis-terra known as mod08_m3 (, platnick et al 2017)
we use c6.1 because the previous collection 6 (c6) showed some artifact trends (levy et al 2018) when compared to modis on aqua (king et al 2013)
since the calibration has been made consistent, c6.1 appears to be largely free of artificial drifts, which we have confirmed via comparisons with modis trends on aqua (supplementary fig

wei et al (2019a) also found c6.1 products were improved relative to c6. wei et al (2019b) found modis c6.1 performed best at capturing temporal variations and was closest to ground-based observations
all these instruments are onboard satellites with sun-synchronous orbits and, besides airs, use optimal estimation approaches to retrieve co columns from measured radiances
a summary of instrument specific details are given in table 1. 2.2.1. airs the airs (airs), on board nasa/aqua was launched in 2002 and crosses the equator at ~13:15 lst (aumann et al 2003)
the 1650 km airs swath provides near global coverage twice daily
radiance spectra from the airs grating spectrometer are used to determine cloud and surface properties along with vertical profiles of atmospheric trace gases (including co at 4.6 m) and t
previous comparisons of airs and mopitt co showed good agreement in horizontal spatial variability, but found airs co to be higher than mopitt (v3) (warner et al 2007)
we use the level 2 v006 airs retrievals here, (airs2ret, airs science team/joao teixeira, 2013), which has 50 km x 50 km spatial resolution
the airs2ret level 2 product was created level-2 using airs ir-only retrievals

2.2.2. iasi there are three infrared atmospheric sounding interferometer (iasi) tir ace-fts (fts) instruments currently in orbit: iasi-a, b, and c onboard the eumetsat satellites metop-a, b and c, launched in 2006, 2012, and 2018, respectively
2.2.3. tes the tropospheric emission spectrometer (tes) was launched on the nasa/aura satellite in 2004 and crosses the equator at 13:40 lst, 25 minutes after the nasa/aqua satellite

2.2.4. cris the cris (cris) was launched in october 2011 on the suomi-npp (s-npp) satellite (noaa-19) with an equator-crossing time of ~13:30 lst
the cris scan pattern consists of nine detectors (each called a field of view: fov) in a 3×3 pattern (collectively named a field of regard: for)
the cris cross-track scan consists of thirty earth-view fors, plus additional calibration fors
cris is a fts operating in three spectral bands between 648 cm 1 and 2555 cm 1, including the co tir r-branch above 2155 cm 1. cris achieves daily coverage of over 95% of earth's surface

here we use cris retrievals processed by the multi-spectra, multi-species, multi-sensors (muses) algorithm (fu et al 2016), which performs single pixel (fov) retrievals, and has heritage in the tes algorithm (egworden et al 2007; luo et al 2013), using the same kulawik et al (2006) approach for retrievals of cloud
in order to expedite analysis, sub-sampling of observations was tested to ensure that the nh and sh cris monthly averages were insensitive to the sub-sampling employed (appendix a1.2)

cloud-screening was performed, using an effective cloud optical threshold of 0.1. while there are operational cris co products available for the for from nucaps (noaa unique combined atmospheric processing system, gambacorta, 2013), we instead use the muses single pixel (fov) retrievals to take advantage of the full cris co spatial resolution and error characterization derived from optimal estimation

the dutch-finnish omi sensor onboard the earth observing system (eos) aura satellite platform, which was launched on july 15th, 2004, provides measurements of the spectral region spanning wavelengths of 264-504 nm (nanometers) with a spectral resolution of 0.42-0.63 nm and enhanced spatial (up to 13 × 24 km2) and temporal (daily) resolutions with global coverage (lamsal et al 2008; omi team, 2012)
the aura satellite orbits at an altitude of 705 km in a sun-synchronous polar orbit, passing over each location with a local bypass time during 12:00-15:00 pm (schoeberl et al 2006)

the omi-no2 level-2 algorithm retrieves estimated columns (total, stratospheric, and tropospheric; unit: molecules/cm2, abbreviated as molec/cm2) of no2 from the omi level-1b calibrated radiance and irradiance data; specifically, the columns used in this study were retrieved with the current version 3.0 of the algorithm, which is an improvement over the previous versions (1, 2.0 and 2.1) (omi no2 team, 2016)
the aura satellite passes over each location between 12:00 pm and 3:00 pm local time

thus, the 12-3 pm mean was representative of daily mean of ground no2. therefore, as a proxy variable for the ground no2 mean between 12 pm and 3 pm, the omi-no2 columns could approximately match daily ground no2 in statistical terms
statistics showed that there was a significant correlation (0.44-0.5) between omi-no2 columns and daily mean of ground no2 (p-value < 2.2e-16)

in statistical terms and for practical application, omi-no2 columns were a significant and reliable predictor for daily mean of ground no2. similar methods have been used in many studies (gu et al 2017; xu et al 2019; zhan et al 2018)

for imputation of missing omi-no2 columns, we selected the covariates according to domain and empirical knowledge, which included meteorology, reanalysis data from the merra, version 2 (merra2), elevation and coordinates
as one of the main reasons for missingness of omi-no2 columns, the cloud coverage in the training samples has a small variation, which may limit its use in the imputation models

from the yd08_d3 modis aqua and terra daily l3 global 1deg cma datasets (nasa, 2020a; oreopoulos et al 2014), we extracted the daily cloud fraction to estimate ground no2. high-accuracy 1 × 1 km2 grids of the meteorological variables were generated using a residual deep network to fuse the ground measurements, merra2 reanalysis data, coordinates and elevations (fang and li, 2019; li, 2019)
the merra2 reanalysis data provided reliable coarsespatial-resolution estimates of surface meteorological data

the coarse-resolution merra2 pblh and o3 data were downscaled using the covariates of elevation and coordinates, and the algorithm (li et al 2020b) to obtain 1 × 1 km2 grids and used as two major covariates for the imputation of omi-no2. due to complex atmospheric chemical and physical processes involved in the cloud forming (wiki, 2020), for simplicity, the cloud fraction was downscaled using the bilinear interpolation

the coordinates (latitude and longitude, unit: degree) and additional variables derived from the coordinates (their squares and product) were collectively used as five predictors in the imputation models to capture the spatial variations of omi-no2. the coordinates were reported to reliably capture spatial trends in estimation of ground-level no2 and they should be able to account for similar spatial trend in estimation of no2 columns

the 1 × 1 km2 elevation surface from the sea level was used in downscaling and imputation to account for the altitude-related variability of omi-no2. in order to estimate ground-level no2, in addition to imputed omino2, as well as meteorology, coordinate, elevation etc
for images of different spatial scales (eg merra2 pblh and o3) and projections, reprojection and bilinear resampling or downscaling were used to obtain a consistent projection and spatial scale
in order to cover the large study region, multiple tiles of omi-no2 were mosaic and cropped

similar deep learning methods have been used with high accuracy in the fusion of meteorological measurements and merra2 data, the imputation of maiac aod data and the estimation of pm2.5. for more information and technical details about residual regression networks, please refer to (li et al 2020a; li et al 2020b)

for downscaling and imputation of omi-no2 columns, meteorology (air t, relative humidity and wind speed), merra2 reanalysis data (pblh and o3), elevation, coordinates and their derivatives (x, y, x2, y2 and xy) were used as predictor variables; relevant parameters can be shared among multiple outputs for multiple variables, thus serving as a regularizer to improve the generalizability and reduce overfitting
due to the intractable sample size, it is impractical to merge all the 365-day pixellevel samples in 2015 into a data set to train a single model of omi-no2 columns

4. procedure for imputation of missing omi-no2 and estimation of ground-level no2. where l(w, b) is the loss function of mean square error (mse) to be optimized; x is the matrix of the input predictor variables; y is the vector of the target variable (ground-truth omi-no2); yw,b (x) represents the imputed values of missing omi-no2 data points based on the input covariates x and the parameters w, b (where w and b are the matrices of the weights and biases, respectively, in the neural network to be solved using gradient descent (goodfellow et al 2016)); fw, b(x) is the estimate of the input x generated by the residual network; y and x are the mse loss functions for y and x, respectively; and n is the mini-batch sample size

the complete (raw observed and imputed) omi-no2 columns will be converted to the ground-level no2 coefficient using the empirical relationship with pblh and relative humidity, similar to aod's conversion (wang et al 2010)

compared with the satellite data of omi-no2 columns, the sample size of ground no2 measurement data is much smaller, so all the ground no2 measurement samples for all 365 days in 2015 were merged into one data set to train a single base model

given a small size of ground-level no2 samples, different from the large size of omi-no2 samples, the input was not included in the output as regularizer in the base residual deep network of ground-level no2. for bagging (fig

4. the following paragraphs briefly describe specific common steps of the procedure: 1) collecting and filtering of satellite data (ie omi-no2) and groundlevel no2 measurements

this step involved collecting and processing of data and filtering of invalid values (eg using the rowanomaly/cloud/snow flag to filter out invalid or questionable no2 columns (omi team, 2012); valid ground-level no2 extracted)
in this step, the data of merra2 and other spatial and/or temporal variables (eg meteorology, elevation, coordinates) were extracted and integrated with satellite data
however, the inclusion of outliers in the model may introduce bias, which may potentially lead to overestimation of low omi-no2 or ground no2 concentration

(1) for the loss function) is an empirically optimal choice to reduce over-fitting in omi-no2 imputation, and the output of a single target variable is an empirically optimal choice for ground no2 estimation

for imputation of missing satellite no2 columns, given the high spatial and temporal resolutions of many of the input predictor variables, including the meteorological data, projected coordinates and elevations, the coarse-resolution (up to 13 × 24 km2) omi-no2 data were downscaled to a target grid with a high spatial (1 × 1 km2) and temporal (daily) resolution

first, the original daily-level omi-no2 data were initially resampled onto a 1 × 1 km2 grid using bilinear interpolation, and then, the imputation models were trained to downscale and impute omi-no2 columns
the following paragraphs briefly describe the steps of training, validation and inference for imputation of omi-no2 columns
1) training of daily models of omi-no2 columns

for the imputation model of omi-no2, the typical hyper-parameters in deep learning (goodfellow et al 2016) included learning rate, mini-batch training sample size, network structure (number of hidden layers and number of nodes in each hidden layer) and number of learning echoes
each trained model could be used to infer the estimates of the missing omi-no2 columns for the corresponding day

as a traffic-related criteria pollutant, no2 has a high spatial gradient in urban areas, quite different from regional pm2.5. hence, the omi-no2 was downscaled to spatial resolution of 1 km to provide better spatial variation at a fine spatial resolution than that at a coarse spatial resolution
there is no change in temporal resolution since the resolution of the original omi-no2 and that of the imputed output has the same temporal resolution (daily)
the covariates of imputed omi-no2, meteorology, merra2, elevation, coordinates, traffic and land-use was used to train multiple base models

5. overall 2015 mean distribution (a) and seasonal mean distributions (b for spring, c for summer, d for autumn and e for winter) of omi-no2. imputation of the missing omi-no2 data, the sample data from each day were randomly split into three subsets: approximately 64% of the samples were used for training, 18% of the samples were used for validation and 18% of the samples were used for testing

additionally, the spatial distributions of both the observed and imputed omi-no2 columns were examined to determine whether the smoothness of the spatial transitions between the observed and imputed data and their overall distributions were reasonable

with the available observed and imputed omi-no2 data and the other covariates, ground-level no2 could be predicted using ensemble residual deep networks; thus, corresponding models were trained to examine the use of observed and imputed omi-no2 columns in the inference of ground-level no2. for this evaluation, the test r2 and rmse between the observed and predicted ground-level no2 values were calculated and reported

for imputation of omi-no2, the mean of the importance scores of each feature (predictor variable) in all the daily models was summarized; for estimation of ground no2, the feature importance was reported
given the complex chemistry of no2 affected by multiple factors, temporal (seasonal) variation of the correlations between each predictor and omi-no2 was quantified and analyzed

predicted mean no2 for a winter day of 2015. whereas exposure estimation of ground-level no2 at a high spatiotemporal resolution across a large study region is constrained by the limited availability of monitoring data and related covariates (eg publicly accessible traffic density), satellite-borne data such as omi-no2 columns can be used as an important predictor for ground-level no2, with global spatial coverage and a high temporal resolution (omi no2 team, 2016)
however, the coarse spatial resolution and extensive nonrandom missing values of omi-no2 columns negatively affect the application of the column data to infer ground-level no2 at a fine scale

using a full residual deep network, this paper reliably downscaled and imputed missing omi-no2 columns to a high spatial (1 × 1 km2) and temporal (daily) resolution for a large region (ie most of mainland china); with bagging of residual deep networks, as well as the predictors of imputed omi-no2, meteorology, and local traffic and land-use variables etc

the proposed method can generate more consistent and reliable estimates of missing omi-no2 than the recent methods (de hoogh et al 2019; di et al 2020; zhan et al 2018), and consequently extensively predict ground-level no2 concentrations

in the presented method, the learning curve approached a plateau after a small number (eg 20) of training epochs, and a small standard deviation (0.01) of the test r2 was obtained among daily models of 2015, demonstrating the method's stability and robustness in the imputation of missing omi-no2 columns, and subsequent estimation of ground-level no2 concentration

in a viable training time and with the outliers removed, the trained full residual deep network achieved a mean test r2 of 0.98 for omi-no2 downscaled imputation, much better than the r2 of 0.36 achieved through linear regression, and was superior to the mixed model (mean validation r2: 0.68) recently used by de hoogh et al (2019), temporal convolution (zhan et al 2018) and substitution with the output of chemical transport model (di et al 2020)

compared with the previous methods, our imputation achieved a better test performance with limited covariates, including the coordinates, and their squares and product, meteorological parameters (air t, wind speed, relative humidity), merra2 variables (pblh and o3), and elevation

as shown by the test performance (r2 > 0.9), our imputation method proved to be an effective solution, which could capture the significant relationship between meteorology and spatial variability (represented by the coordinates and their derivatives, and elevation), and omi-no2. our method reliably imputed non-random missing omi-no2 that was mainly caused by row anomaly and other reasons

in addition, with powerful capacity of the full residual deep network to model non-linear relationships, the corresponding imputation models were trained based on the downscaled samples at a higher spatial (1 × 1 km2) resolution than spatial resolution of the samples from other satellites such as tropomi (3.6 km × 5.6 km) (esa, 2020c) and the gems (3.5 km × 8 km) (kim et al 2020)

given the availability of prediction covariates, our method can be used to estimate the missing values of no2 columns of these high-resolution satellites launched in recent years, as well as the missing values of omi-no2 columns available since 2004. for the prediction variables involved in imputation, projected coordinates were used in the models to capture the spatial variability of fig

predicted mean no2 for a winter day of 2015 omi-no2, and the gridded results showed a clear spatial pattern (ie higher values in eastern china than in western china); meteorological factors and merra2 reanalysis data were used to capture spatiotemporal variability of omi-no2. multiple emission sources, meteorological parameters and vertical mixing interactively affected the no2 columns, and the relationships among them presented non-linear seasonal variations (supplementary fig
typically, the analysis showed a higher correlation of air t with omi-no2 in summer and autumn than in winter and spring
relative humidity had a higher correlation with omi-no2 in autumn and early winter than in the other seasons
the test showed a stable performance in imputation of omi-no2 across 365 days of 2015 with a slight seasonal variation (lower rmse and standard deviation in summer than in winter)

many omi-no2 columns are non-randomly missing due to the presence of clouds or high surface reflectance (bechle et al 2013; de nazelle et al 2010), which may prevent sunlight for photolysis of ground-level no2 and no

therefore, the influence of clouds may cause the omi-no2 columns imputed using the observed samples to overestimate ground-level no2 (bai et al 1999; hall et al 2018) (mean ground-level no2 in our case study: 41 g/m3 for cloudless conditions vs
this may explain why the imputed omi-no2 columns showed a lower correlation with ground-level no2 than the raw observed omi-no2 columns did (0.5 vs
the overall correlation of the observed and imputed omi-no2 columns with the ground-level no2 measurements was 0.48, similar to that (0.5) of the observed omi-no2 columns
the results show the reliability of using observed and imputed omi-no2 columns to infer ground-level no2. the observed and imputed no2 column data exhibited a moderate fig

as indicated in jia et al (2016), omi-no2 does not well match ground-level no2 in urban areas due to high gradient of spatial variation compared with rural areas, and thus the correlation is not so high
thus, in spatiotemporal estimation of ground-level no2 using the omi-no2, we also extracted additional traffic, poi and land-use variables from the open street data sources
the predicted ground no2 surfaces showed significantly higher concentrations near road but the imputed and downscaled omi-no2 grids did not show this pattern

the omi-no2 failed to reveal highresolution variations in no2. the predicted no2 spatial distribution could be modified by local variables (including road length, distance to the road and poi, and land-use proportions) to enhance high variability near the road

the surfaces of ensemble predicted no2 not only showed consistent spatial distributions with omi-no2 columns at a regional and temporal scale, but also presented local spatial gradients or variability of ground-level no2 at a fine local scale

first, although downscaling in imputation of satellite no2 columns highlights local contrasts at a fine spatial resolution, the resultant outputs are still constrained to the background scale (the coarse resolution of the raw omi-no2)

this paper presents the use of a full residual network to impute extensive missing satellite-borne no2 data (ie omi-no2 columns), and bagging of base residual networks to reliably estimate ground-level no2 concentrations at a high spatial (1 × 1 km2) and temporal (daily) resolution for a large study region (ie most of mainland china)

compared with the existing linear and nonlinear methods, the proposed method has high learning efficiency with improved generalizability (for imputation of omi-no2: mean test r2 of 0.98 and mean test rmse of 0.42 × 1015 molec/cm2; for estimation of ground-level no2, mean test r2 of 0.80 and mean test rmse of 9.2 g/m3)

the final 1 × 1 km2 grids showed natural and smooth spatial transitions between the observed and imputed omi-no2, and between ensemble predicted ground-level no2 concentrations (with estimated coefficients of variation), indicating the reliability of the presented method for imputation of omino2 columns and spatiotemporal estimation of ground-level no2 in a large study region

the prediction variables used (including meteorology, merra2, and local traffic and land-use variables deriving from open street) are available globally, so our proposed method has broad applicability

2.1. oco-2 data oco-2 is an atmospheric co2 observing satellite launched by national aeronautics and space administration (nasa) in 2014, flying in a 705 km sun-synchronous near-polar orbit with equator crossing time near 13:36 (local time) and a 16-day ground track repeat cycle (osterman et al 2018)
oco-2 makes observations by using 8 adjacent soundings across a swath no wide than 10 km
oco-2 is routinely making around 1 million observations each day, and more than 10% of these observations are sufficiently cloud-free to retrieve xco2 precisely (osterman et al 2018)
the xco2 retrieved from oco-2 observations have a median difference of less than 0.5 ppm and root mean square differences typically below 1.5 ppm compared with tccon (wunch et al 2017)

in this study, by adding an observation operator module and a xco2 retrievals aggregation module, and by modifying existing modules, the dart was extended to be able to assimilate the oco-2 xco2 retrievals

the xco2 retrievals from nadir observation mode with good quality according to the xco2_quality_flag were selected from the latest version of oco-2 level 2 (l2) lite data product v9r (oco-2 science team/michael gunson and eldering, 2018)

merra-2 is a global atmospheric reanalysis produced by the national aeronautics and space administration (nasa) using the goddard earth observing system model version 5 (goes-5) with its atmospheric data assimilation system (adas) version 5.12.4. it has a horizontal resolution of 0.625◦ × 0.5◦, 72 vertical levels going from 985 to 0.01 hpa (from the troposphere to the upper mesosphere) and covers the period 1980-present

in essence, the analysis below utilizes a full atmospheric reanalysis (merra-2; section 2a) to characterize the behavior of both the land surface and its meteorological drivers, and it then uses this characterization as the basis for a simple water balance framework that can produce estimates of evapotranspiration and air t at subseasonal leads (sections 2b and 2c)

the merra-2 reanalysis the merra, version 2 (merra-2), produced by the global modeling and assimilation office (gmao) at the national aeronautics and space administration's goddard space flight center (nasa gsfc), is a stateof-the-art atmospheric reanalysis that provides a comprehensive and self-consistent picture of atmospheric and land surface fields over the period 1980-present (gelaro et al 2017)

merra-2 combines a wealth of conventional and satellite-based measurements (mccarty et al 2016) together within a global atmosphere-land surface modeling environment that serves to translate in space and time the information contained in the observations and also to impose additional physical constraints on the evolution of the meteorological fields

merra-2, unique among existing atmospheric reanalyses in its utilization of aerosol information (randles et al 2016), has been evaluated extensively against independent observational datasets (bosilovich et al 2015)
the present analysis uses daily-averaged merra-2 data on a 0.58 latitude 3 0.6258 longitude grid

2.1. measurement techniques the bc concentrations analysed in this study were from two sources: the nasa merra, version 2 (merra-2) reanalysis and the aethalometer measurements within nsw dpie air quality monitoring network

satellite data products from modis aqua/terra and lidar data from caliop (cloud-aerosol lidar with orthogonal polarization) instrument on calipso (cloud-aerosol lidar and infrared pathfinder satellite observation) satellite were also used to detect the hot spots of biomass burnings as sources of bc emission and smoke plumes

in our study, hysplit was run at with gdas (gdas) data at a spatial resolution of 0.25. the backward trajectories predicted by hysplit having particles released at 10 m for 24 or 48 h were used to determine the location of biomass burning sources that caused high concentration of bc and pm2.5 as measured at the monitoring sites
2.2.3. the merra-2 reanalysis bc predicted surface concentration from the global merra-2 reanalysis model was used to study the bc spatial distribution across nsw

the merra-2 reanalysis data produced by nasa's global modelling and assimilation office (gmao) were downloaded from ?&path=/geos-5. the bc concentrations at the surface level, as a component of the merra aerosol reanalysis (merraero) with a 0.5-degree spatial resolution and 3-h interval, were extracted

the merraero is based on geos-5 which is radiatively coupled to the goddard chemistry, aerosol, radiation and transport (gocart) aerosol module and includes assimilation of aerosol optical depth (aod) from the modis sensor aboard the aqua/terra satellites, ground-based aeronet aod data
the geos-5 gocart module, as described in , includes 15 aerosol tracers, such as dust, sea salt, sulphate, black and organic carbon, o3, co and co2
merra-2 aerosol assimilation data product for geos-5 allows one to distinguish among various emission sources of bc

we have taken the daily total column observations of hcho as available from the omi (omi) on the aura satellite
omi has a cross-track field of view of 115◦, swath of 2600 km, with pixel size between 13 × 24 km2 at nadir and 26 × 135 km2 at the swath edges
the omi hcho gridding algorithm filters out pixels affected by row anomalies (gonzalez abad et al 2015)

the level 3 data were interpolated to 0.1 ◦ × 0.1 ◦ grids and are filtered to remove high cloud fractions (>0.3), solar zenith angle (sza >70◦), and the columns affected by omi row anomalies (chance, 2019; ahmad et al 2003)

at each target 0.1 ◦ × 0.1 ◦ grid, the omi hcho algorithm calculates weighted-average for vertical column amounts, column uncertainties, air mass factors, cloud fraction, cloud pressure, terrain height, and albedo using omhcho l2 product as input
a detailed description of the instrument and its working procedure are given in levelt et al (2018) and gonzalez abad et al (2015), and the validation of omi hcho can be found in zhu et al (2016)
since omi has row anomalies and instrumental error due to aging, a significant drift in omi data is observed from 2015 onwards
a visible change and oscillations in the omi measurements are noticed after 2014 (not shown)
the total error of omi hcho vertical column under biogenically enhanced conditions is 25%

2.1. moderate resolution imaging spectroradiometer (modis) data the moderate resolution imaging spectrora- diometer (modis) is an imaging radiometer launched by the national aeronautics and space administration (nasa) aboard the terra (eos am) satellite in 1999 as well as aboard the aqua (eos pm) satellite in 2002. it can capture data in 36 spectral bands covering a wide spectral range from visible to thermal infrared bands (0.40-14.38 lm) which gives atmospheric, oceanic and terrestrial information (savtchenko et al 2004; remer et al 2005)
modis usually detects mid and high level clouds but usually finds difficult to capture low-level clouds
for the selected study region, it is observed that almost all types of cloud are present over indian ocean but study would highly depend upon observation capabilities of modis (dey et al 2015)
specifically, mid and high-level cumulus and stratus type of clouds would be easily accessible by modis, whereas clouds undetected by modis will be missing in the present study
modis detect clear and cloudy conditions of each pixel depending on spatial variability (ackerman et al 1998)
along with aod, cer was also taken from modis which retrieve data at three near infrared bands (1.6 lm, 2.1 lm and 3.7 lm)
cloud retrieval method of modis has advantage of differentiating liquid and ice phase to represent warm and cold cloud
the error in modis retrieved cer is approximately less than 0.1 lm which has cloud optical thickness of 50 (king et al 1997)
also, modis retrieved aod has an expected error of (0.03 ? 0.05aod) over ocean (remer et al 2005)

present study uses level 3 monthly averaged data of aod and cer from modis/terra during 2001 to 2016, at spatial resolution of 1 9 1 from giovanni online portal which is developed and maintained by the national aeronautics and space administration, goddard earth sciences data and information services center (acker and leptoukh 2007; giovanni 2019)
the meera-2 is a nasa atmospheric reanalysis data, made using an upgraded version of the goddard earth observing system model, version 5 (geos-5)
all data collections from merra-2 are provided on the same horizontal grid
this approach is similar to the gauge-based precipitation forcing developed for merra-land (reichle and liu 2014)
the forcing precipitation is not purely gauge observations, as it tapers back to merra-2 model generated precipitation

2.3. precipitation estimates precipitation estimates based on the gldas, merra, trmm, gpm, and gpcp products as summarized in table 2 were obtained from giovanni platform of the national aeronautics and space administration (nasa) ()

products gldas merra trmm gpm gpcp daily/monthly/annual daily/monthly/annual daily/monthly/annual daily/monthly/annual monthly/annual the gldas uses global land surface models to generate (develop) near real time products land surface fluxes and states by ingesting (being forced by ground- and satellitebased data )
since its development, gldas has developed a number of versions with improved products based on noah, vic, mosaic, and catchment-lsms

it should be noted that the gldas 2.1 was the forces with the gpcp v1.3 daily precipitation fields between 2000-2001 and agremet since 2001. the merra version 2 is a reanalysis of satellite observations projected conducted by the nasa global modeling and assimilation office (gmao)

merra uses the goddard earth observing system version 5 (goes-5) model focusing on historic climate analysis, and its dataset provides precipitation estimates based on a large number of satellite observations and general circulation models in combination with weather stations observation to parameterize initial conditions
version 5.12.4 of merra-2 uses microwave and hyperspectral infrared measurements, and it is available at 1 h temporal resolution
the tmpa (tmpa) provided precipitation estimates by combining data from 3 sensors ie precipitation radar (pr), microwave imager (tmi), and visible and infrared (virs), as well as gauge observations
trmm era data is available from 1997 until 2019 as it seized operation in 2015. the science community transitioned to the gpm that was launched in 2014 with its improved precipitation product
the trmm 3b42 v7 product was developed to maximize the quality of precipitation data for applied research in meteorology and hydrology globally

it should be noted that more consistent trmm 3b42 v7 data were the one available for the period between january 1998 to september 2014. after this period until december 2019, the 3b42 v7 algorithm was processed in parallel with gpm (imerg)
the trmm data were available at the daily time scale-the same temporal resolution of that of the measurements
the gpm is considered a successor of trmm with enhanced rain and snow observation
the gpm core observatory was launched in february 2014 with dpr (dpr) and gpm microwave imager (gmi) instruments to create a global precipitation dataset

the gpm has uses its integrated multi-satellite retrievals (imerg) algorithm to develop a global precipitation dataset from a satellite constellation in collaboration with international members (ie 6 passive microwave radiometers and 5 geosynchronous infrared sensors)
the imerg algorithm also fuses trmm historic data (from 2000 to 2015) with the recent gpm (ie dpr and gmi) observations (from 2014 onward) to provide long-term precipitation dataset
the highest temporal resolution of gpm is 30 min and was accumulated and processed by the ges disc to the daily time scale

it should be noted that while gpm and trmm mostly use the same input datasets, their different algorithms used in producing these estimates allowed gpm to provide its high frequency precipitation values (30 min)
one of these five datasets include trmm composite climatology (tcc) which was developed to be used for global scale modeling such as gcm

2.4. performance indicators the daily, monthly, and annual precipitation estimates as provided by these different products were analyzed only when there were no data gaps in the corresponding observations from conventional weather stations
the geographic location of each weather stations was matched with a corresponding pixel (closest to the center of a pixel) of the gridded products (ie from remote sensing and reanalysis) (figure 2)

3. results 3.1. assessment of temporal accuracy the daily precipitation estimates by the trmm consistently overestimated the corresponding measurements by about 4.7%
monthly and annual precipitation estimates by trmm were not significant different from the corresponding measurements
precipitation estimates by merra consistently underestimated observations by an average of about 22.9% on the three-time scales (ie daily, monthly, and annual)
the precipitation estimated by the gldas and gpm products did not differ significantly on all the three-time scales (daily, monthly, and annual) when compared with the measurements
a relatively similar performance by the trmm was also observed at the monthly and annual precipitation estimates and by the gpcp at the monthly precipitation estimates (figure 3)
precipitation estimates by merra consistently underestimated observations by an average of about 22.9% on the three-time scales (ie daily, monthly, and annual)
the precipitation estimated by the gldas and gpm products did not differ significantly on all the three-time scales (daily, monthly, and annual) when comwater 2021, 13, 333pared with the measurements
a relatively similar performance by the trmm was also observed at the monthly and annual precipitation estimates and by the gpcp at the monthly precipitation estimates (figure 3)

amluoersecolovseer,,, the spatial differences between precipitation estimates by remote sensing and reanalysis, and the measurements at the weather stations can be partly due to differences in the spatial scales represented by these techniques
the gldas product uses data from several satellites and rain gauges in its model
the satellite information is based on infrared and microwave sensors, including the trmm satellite, which justified its relatively improved results

on the other hand, there are some uncertainties that can occur in the data used in developing the gldas product, due to the small number of rain gauges and the quality of their measurements in the region

as with the gldas product, gpcp uncertainties may increase due to the fact that this product uses and combines indirect estimates of precipitation from satellite sensors (visible, infrared, and microwave) as well as rain gauges to calibrate its input data
the merra product had noticeable limitations as it underestimated precipitation in all locations, and it percutaneously estimated precipitation events that were not measured at the weather stations

moreover, merra uses average surface precipitation data (rain gauges) to establish its initial conditions from the national oceanic and atmospheric administration (noaa) unified gauge-based analysis of global daily precipitation
there was not enough information available about how many precipitation stations within mato grosso were directly used in developing merra, if any

the study by indicated that merra estimates showed increased error in the amazon due to sharp decline in the number of precipitation stations used in merra from 350 between 1980-2004 to only 65 since 2004. precipitation estimates by merra are closely dependent on the geos-5 catchment-lsm, which can also be highly sensitive to changes in other hydrological variables

in addition, the precipitation measurements used as input in the geos-5 model can generate uncertainty in the estimates because the model and the calibration period of the instruments are heterogeneous

a study carried out in the central region of south america, evaluated the merra estimates based on an earlier version of this product and found an opposite relationship with the surface precipitation data
the study justified this error due to the low density of installed rain gauges in this region

5. conclusions the objective of the study was to compare precipitation estimates based on remote sensing from gpm, trmm, and gpcp; and reanalysis from gldas and merra products with measurements from conventional weather stations over the state of mato grosso
precipitation estimates by the remote sensing products from gpm, trmm, and gpcp had better performance compared to those based on reanalysis from gldas and merra
precipitation products from gpm have an advantage over those from trmm and gpcp
the performance of gpm and trmm products, from high to low, was followed by those from the gpcp and gldas while merra showed the lowest performance

spatially, precipitation estimates by trmm, gpm, gpcp, and gldas showed higher correlation coefficients, from high to low, and lower errors, from low to high, respectively within the amazon biome in the northern region than in the cerrado and pantanal in the southern regions of mato grosso
in contrast, merra estimates showed lower correlation and higher errors in all regions of the state
finally, this study also indicated that it is important to increase the number of weather stations to allow for a more spatially representative evaluation of precipitation estimates and measurement

3.2.1. gpm precipitation product gpm core satellite jointly developed by japan and the united states carries two observation instruments, namely the dpr (dpr) developed by japan aerospace exploration agency (jaxa) and the gpm microwave imager (gmi) developed by the national aeronautics and space administration (nasa)
the gpm mission combines multiple precipitation estimates from independent sensors
the gpm core satellite has the ability to observe tropical regions and mid-to high-latitude areas with an orbit inclination of 65 degrees
the dpr aboard the gpm core satellite is composed of two precipitation radars (prs), the ku pr operating at ku-band (13.6 ghz) and the ka pr at ka-band (35.5 ghz) (hou et al 2014)
the dpr's swath width was about 245 km for the 13.6 ghz radar, and about 125 km for the 35.5 ghz radar (hou et al 2014) over the study period
the gmi has 13 channels with a frequency range from 10 to 183 ghz with a swath width about 900 km (hou et al 2014)
the gpm data products are available in levels 1, 2, and 3 as per the standard nomenclature

the gpm mission was commenced with an objective to provide more accurate estimates of the rate of transfer of water from the atmosphere to the surface at local and global scales thereby reducing the source of uncertainty in the global water and energy budget
for the present study, the gpm level 2 orbital product from dpr 2a-ku precipitation radar (hereafter it is referred as dpr) is used for the time period of 2 years (2015 and 2016)
in this study, we assess the optimum temporal integration time of the dpr for hydrological applications
to the best of the authors' knowledge this is the first study towards the quantification of uncertainty in hydrological fluxes caused to sampling intermittency of dpr orbital data
in order to overcome the low sampling frequency of dpr, we utilize the srem2d model to simulate dpr uniformly throughout the study area

our intention is not to estimate the error of dpr orbital precipitation data but rather to understand the implication of likely dpr sampling errors for the simulation of hydrological fluxes and states

in this study, we estimate sampling errors of space time rainfall averages sampled by the gpm constellation satellites by aggregating them over a space scale of 0.25 degree and time scales of 3, 6 and 12 h
therefore, to address this issue in our methodology we have used the srem2d model which corrupts the reference data with the error characteristics of dpr (which includes the sampling error)

the main aim of the srem2d model in our methodology is to generate ensembles of aggregated precipitation forcing at intervals of 3hrs, 6hrs and 12hrs representing the sampling intervals of dpr orbital product
the first section involves gridding of the dpr orbital data

the second section describes the formulation of the satellite rainfall error model used to simulate synthetic dpr rainfall retrievals by corrupting the reference rainfall with the sampling error characteristics of dpr orbital data
this step ensures that the synthetic dpr precipitation retrievals have the same sampling characteristics as that of dpr data

the srem2d parameters are calibrated for the regridded dpr sensor for the years 2015 and 2016. srem2d ensembles are generated by perturbing the cmorph reference precipitation with dpr error characteristics
the ensembles represent dpr precipitation retrievals when the reference precipitation ie cmorph is perturbed with the dpr error characteristics for sampling intervals of 3-hour, 6-hour and 12-hour
the dpr error characteristic expresses the mean behaviour that accounts the space-time correlations and intermittency in the satellite precipitation ifelds
the dpr orbital data sampling error can then be propagated through the vic model in terms of ensembles of forcing data as input, and the output is the uncertainty bound of streamflow
the intermittent gpm level 2 orbital data (referring to dpr) is available at the footprint size of 5 km × 5 km
dpr sampling errors are complicated functions of sampling geometry and statistical properties of the measured fields (ganesh et al 2019; indu and nagesh kumar, 2014)
e the reference precipitation, the dpr orbital data is gridded to 0.25 degree × 0.25 degree spatial resolution
the gridded dpr precipitation can then be accumulated to 3-hourly, 6-hourly and 12-hourly temporal integration time as shown in step 2 in fig
3. dpr gridded data are obtained at 0.25 degree × 0.25 degree spatial resolution and 3hourly, 6-hourly and 12-hourly temporal integration time
the fundamental objective of our study is to investigate how the dpr sampling errors propagate through the vic hydrological model
hence, ensembles of synthetic dpr precipitation retrievals simulated using the srem2d is used as forcing data in the calibrated vic model

the average values of the calibrated parameters for all cases are as follows: the pod 0.96, far 4.30, mean gaussian log error is 1.2, the standard deviation of gaussian log error is 1.8 and the lag one autocorrelation is 0.57 and are mentioned in table 4. the probability of rain detection for dpr for the year 2015 and 2016 are presented in fig
7 illustrates the cumulative hyetographs where the 100 ensemble realizations obtained by perturbing the dpr error seems to be consistent

as calibration period was selected based on the availability of both the dpr orbital data and in situ streamflow data, we have the common data period available during two years only from 2015 to 2016. therefore, due to the low availability of datasets we have performed calibration annually, which is the primary reason for the positive bias
